name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the Pascal Durand report on differentiated integration (2018/2093(INI)) (A8-0402/2018).

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, thank you, Commissioner, for being here, we feel a little less alone and it warms the soul a little in this morning. First of all, I would like to thank, since they are here, the representatives of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, all those who have worked with me, and in particular Mr Juregui, who has worked not only in this report, but also in the context of his report. This report on differentiated integration is a follow-up to the Commission's proposal, namely the famous five scenarios that President Juncker had come to present here. This report is part of the Commission's third proposal, which is obviously in the favour of the European Parliament, namely a Europe that is progressing and a Europe that allows those who want to move forward to be able to move forward. It is with this in spirit that we present this report. We are in a moment - I do not need to stress this issue - very particular for the European Union. There is Brexit, there is the difficulty of being heard by citizens, but above all there is the danger of entering a multi-speed Europe: a Europe of first class for some, a Europe of second or even third class for others. We have to keep our unity, that's the challenge we're trying to meet together. The report opens up a number of avenues. It opens up avenues within the treaty and makes proposals for the future. Within the Treaty, we insist - and Parliament really insists very strongly - that the 'bridge' clause be implemented and used to move away from the logic of unanimity that blocks decisions. We also want the opt out to end. The primary law must be the same for everyone and, if new entrants want to come, either they accept the full primary right or we go through a logic of partnership agreements. It is very important to ensure that primary law is the same for all countries, that there are no different levels of country with regard to primary law. This is very important to us. We also hope that the European Union can put this fundamental values and rights in force very clearly and that we do not have the capacity, in a differentiated Europe, to back down on these fundamental rights. Apart from that, I will end with the evolutions we can have. We really want to put in place within the European Union a pillar of social, environmental and economic rights, which would ensure that this European Union has a real basis and that it can move forward on these conditions. That is the direction we want overall. Mr President, I would stress that we must ensure that this Europe moves forward with one voice and that we do not have a multi-speed, multi-class Europe, but that those who want to move forward can do so.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, first of all, the subject we are discussing is particularly interesting, but of course we do not have the necessary involvement. Integration, in any case, is differentiated at European Union level, because we have Schengen, in which specific Member States participate, or the euro area. Therefore, it is something that we know about. Secondly, we have some states that have taken exceptions with specific protocols at the level of primary Community law, such as Denmark which is excluded from specific regulations, or also Ireland. I would therefore say that the regulation for countries wishing to move forward is again institutionally envisaged as differentiated integration and is therefore something that now depends politically on which countries should use and whether they want to use this issue to move forward with cooperation on social or environmental issues. I would say, however, that we must also look at this: some countries, because of particular problems, such as Greece, which has been in a memorandum all these years, cannot easily participate on an equal footing with the others. That is why we may have to provide within the Treaty for certain exceptions for countries that have fallen behind, a special liability regime for a period of time in order to be able to relieve these countries and follow the integration process along the way.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Mr President, differentiated integration is a vague, confusing and therefore difficult term by which certain States of the European Union and circles of the European Union are trying to disguise a dangerous objective they have set for the future of Europe. That is to say, the abolition of the current structure of Europe and the creation of a multi-speed Europe, in which the principle of equality has been abolished and some states will be stronger than the rest. The other states will turn into pares, be sidelined and, if allowed, continue along the way. The whole situation reminds me of the well-known phrase from Orwell's work "The Animal Farm" that all animals are equal but some are more equal than others. In order to achieve this objective, the principle of unanimity in European Union decision-making must be abolished. In other words, the power of states will be weakened and the small states in particular will not be able to support their interests. Since I referred to Orwell, I will close my speech by saying this: if we do not react to this dangerous method, then the European Union is obliged to live in Orwell's '1984' and, of course, to be destroyed.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.))

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work You just say: all animals are equal, but some animals are more equal. They allude to the fact that there are large Member States and small Member States. But would you agree that with 27, 28 states, we cannot always wait for everyone to be willing or able to do something? Would you agree that it must be possible for some states to move forward, as has already happened, and for the door to be open to all? So all animals are the same, but some animals are faster than the others, and some are slower. That is the situation.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: answer a question with a blue card. – Mr President, as you know, and as we all know, the European Union is based on certain principles and certain values. Some of these principles are the principle of equality, the principle of solidarity and the principle of cooperation. So in this Union all states must be equal and cooperate with each other. The strongest states must not impose their will on the others. A way of understanding and cooperation must be found. There are a number of issues which are dealt with in the light of the interests of large states and powerful states. That's not supposed to happen. Small states should not be sidelined.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this report is a welcome reaction to the Commission’s White Paper on the future of Europe and to our shared discussion ahead of the Sibiu summit.  As Mr Durand noted, there are different views as to what differentiated integration means and whether it is a good thing or not. Whereas, in some Member States, it is perceived as a positive step towards more integration, other Member States consider it divisive.  The Commission in its White Paper on the future of the EU presented, as you know, five possible scenarios for discussion. Scenario three was an option for some to go further, creating a positive drive towards deeper integration whilst remaining open and inclusive to all who may wish to join. We have seen over the years how this dynamic can help address emerging challenges and drive integration. The euro, now in its 20th year, the EMU and Schengen are examples, and over the years we have seen that more and more Member States have been inspired and have wanted to join such cooperation. I hope and trust that the same will be the case for the permanent structured cooperation (PESCO) since Europeans, now more than ever, need to stand strong in the face of a changed international order. There are also examples in the justice area, like the creation of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, where in 2017, 20 Member States out of 25 Member States – because three had opted out – agreed to engage in enhanced cooperation to establish this key factor to fight crimes against the EU budget. Since then, two more Member States have joined and I am sure that others will eventually follow.  But differentiated integration is only ever the second best. The normal Community method and standard legislative procedure are still the best way to guarantee the integrity and wellbeing of the Union as a whole. It must also remain open to all who wish to join. That is also why the Commission started, last year, and is now pursuing a debate about more efficient and democratic decision-making in specific policy areas by making use of the passerelle clauses foreseen by the existing EU treaties to allow the use of qualified majority voting in areas such as EU foreign policy, EU tax policy or environment.  This will avoid blockages and the need for recourse to enhanced cooperation where unanimity is not forthcoming in these areas and where EU action is close to citizens’ wishes. The Commission looks forward to your support in this.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: This item on the agenda has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 January 2019.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report Jo Lein and Yana Toom on the strategic inquiry of the Ombudsman OI/2/2017 on the transparency of legislative debates taking place in the EU Council preparatory groups (2018/2096(INI)) (A8-0420/2018).

name: Yana TOOM
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Citizens expect decisions and, above all, laws to be comprehensible and comprehensible, which means that the whole decision-making process is transparent. That is what they expect at home in our nation states, and they expect it all the more from the European Union, because Brussels is inevitably further and further away from the people. That is why we also need more transparency at European level than perhaps at national level. We have a situation where this Parliament is an open house. Everything we do can be understood. Our meetings are streamed on the web, our committee meetings are open, our preparatory meetings are open. So we are one of the most transparent parliaments in the world, and we can be proud of that. This is not the case with the other legislative body, the Council of Ministers of the 28 Member States. The Council of Ministers is still a black box, and much is happening behind closed doors. This has improved somewhat, but it is far from the standard we are asking for. And it must be demanded that the second chamber, the Council of Ministers, also have full transparency, not only in the votes on legislation, but also – and this is the point – with the 150 preparatory groups that exist. They are, after all, completely non-transparent. It was a thankful task for the Ombudsmen to take up this issue, and she has, of course, made a report to which we refer. We here in Parliament are also calling for full transparency in the second legislative body, in the Council of Ministers. It should really meet in public, and it should also make the preparatory meetings public. This goes hand in hand with another practice: the secrecy of documents. Most of the documents from the Council have the stamp 'Limité', that is, limited, although nothing is limited in Brussels. We know that every document reaches the public light somewhere; it is therefore a rather antiquated construction. And the Council of Ministers should sort much more carefully what really needs secrecy and what is not actually secret, but is also communicated to the public. Transparency in the Council of Ministers is also necessary because ministers often come from their national capitals, decide something in Brussels and then tell something completely different at home. And they can do that, because no one can understand how they voted. It is also very difficult for us MEPs and for our colleagues in the national parliaments to say how the national government voted. They can tell all sorts of stories that you can believe or not. And that is why, I believe, transparency in the Council of Ministers is also a means of countering conspiracy theories and insinuations. We have so many populists and so many nationalists who like to put any stories into the world. I believe that the time has come to set a good example through transparency and to set us as an example of good governance for the Member States themselves, but also for others in the world. I would therefore like to thank my colleague, Mrs Toom, and all those who have worked to ensure that we vote on this report here today. I hope that we will get a large majority in plenary at 12 noon.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Ombudsman for her work. Almost two years ago, she opened the inquiry on transparency in the Council. She concluded that the current practice in the Council constituted maladministration, especially when it comes to the failure of the Council to register the positions of Member States in the preparatory bodies.  The recommendations she made were very reasonable, but the Council did not answer. Can you imagine? They just did not answer her letter. Therefore, she turned to Parliament to ask for support. During our first meeting on the issue, the Austrian Presidency promised to address the problem, or at least to provide an explanation. But now the Austrian Presidency is over and they never answered either. Hopefully the Romanian Presidency will be different.  Transparency in the Council has been a topic of discussion for 25 years, yet not many things have changed. The small victories in this area, such as access to documents and public deliberations, were pushed for by Parliament and the Ombudsman. This underlines our role in this House as a catalyst for change. While the Council still holds on to the idea that their work is pure diplomacy, the role of the institutions has changed over time. The Council and the Parliament are co—legislators now. Therefore, their practices should be conducted in a similar way. The Parliament has become more transparent. All committee meetings, as Jo Leinen mentioned just now, are open and all reports, minutes and amendments are available. The positions of absolutely each and every Member are clear. It is therefore a logical step that the same should apply to the Council, and the Coreper meetings in particular. It says clearly in the Treaties that decisions should be taken as close to the citizens as possible and, especially now during these turbulent Brexit times, we have to be open and we have to be as close to people as possible. This means that all institutions have the obligation to be open and transparent. It’s crucial for accountability. There is an imbalance between the co—legislators as, when the public is unhappy about an outcome, Member States can easily point their finger at Parliament because our decisions are known, but the public does not see that often the outcome is the result of a struggle between the Parliament and the Council. Perhaps a Member State has a very strong position, yet they blame Brussels. This is problematic for Parliament and also for the media and even national parliaments, who are informed too late about the decisions of their governments in the Council, if at all. Sometimes they are just not informed.  These are the points we have focused on in this report. I would like to thank Jo Leinen for his good cooperation in the committee. Finally, I would like to ask the Chamber to support this report and send the message that this House stands for transparent democratic process.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, transparency in the European legislative process is an essential component in strengthening confidence in the European project.  Citizens must be able to exercise their full right to information on developments in European legislation and must be able to recognise the positions of their representatives, elected directly in this Parliament or indirectly through their governments, in the Council.  Brussels is not and must not be able to be portrayed by its detractors as a black box, in which opaque mediations of interests are needed. This narrative is certainly false, but our commitment as legislators to transparency must nevertheless be maximum.  Parliament and the Commission, as acknowledged by the European Ombudsman himself, have made important steps in recent years to ensure maximum transparency in their preparatory activities. It is therefore important that the Council, as co-legislator, should also commit itself to achieving the highest standards of transparency in its organisation and practices, in accordance with the recommendations of the European Ombudsman, in particular by drawing up clear and well-defined criteria for the classification of so-called 'LIMIT' documents.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Mr President, the issue we are discussing is particularly important. in 1993, I published a book entitled 'The European Ombudsman', in which I raised the issue of transparency and how the European Ombudsman can make concrete interventions. Here, then, we have a theatre of the absurd. The Council has two roles: it is an executive body, but at the same time it is also a legislative body. And, as long as it is a legislative body, there must be transparency. We need to know all the preparatory documents, we need to know every Member State what it says in detail, we need to know what each government is voting for. This is important for the exercise of parliamentary control, because even Members and national parliaments do not know what their government is voting for, and even more so for the citizens who will then be asked to vote for this government or party or to vote against it. So the exhibition opens up specific avenues. The work of the European Ombudsman is very important in order to finally have transparency in the Council, as there is transparency in Parliament, and also to be transparent in the Eurogroup, because that is where important decisions are taken that determine the economy and policy of the whole Of the European Union.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Mr President! Thank you to the rapporteurs and thank you to the Ombudsman, not least, for an excellent report. We are at the very heart of what is being called the democratic deficit in the European Union. It is usually referred to as a kind of ghost story: it is so far away, there are so many, there are so many languages. No, it's exactly at this point we can find it! The national parliaments and the national press do not see what their own government is doing - let alone what the others are doing. Imagine that your own parliament announced just a few times a month that parliament had passed such and such - without you having any idea which party had said what the discussion had been like. That, I would think, would be quite appalling - but that is exactly how the Council works. They work as if they were an intergovernmental institution - not an EU legislative institution. It is diplomats, not civil servants/professionals, who sit and make the laws. You are taking almost no votes - thank you, Ombudsman, for pointing this out - and I really hope that we will not only get good support for this report, but that you are also all making it an important issue in the election campaign to get your governments to support this. Only then will we overcome the democratic deficit in the European Union! (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, I totally agree that little is known and, above all, too fair – or rather incorrect, inequity. In the Member States, citizens do not have the right information about what is happening here, and very often the blame comes to the European Union, not to national administrations or to national parliaments. How do you think we could better inform the citizens of our countries about responsibility at European, national, local level? Because there's, I think, confusion here, and I think it's often done on purpose. There is confusion about subsidiarity, and I think there are mistakes on the part of the European institutions in this regard as well.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Blue-card response. Mr President! I agree with that, of course. That is pretty much what I was trying to describe, but I think, Mrs Grapini, that if we really read the Ombudsman's report and the report we have here, then we have very, very good tools to attack that problem. As soon as the national press and national parliaments can keep up with what their governments are doing, they are forced to see what the other side of the legislative process - namely us - is doing and we have easy access to us. They can easily keep up with what we are doing, so that is not in itself the problem. The problem is that the whole important national layer has been kept out of democracy, and I very much hope that together we can fight evil, and with the Ombudsman's report we have an excellent tool to do so.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this Europe is often perceived, all too often, as far removed from European citizens and, speaking to people, it is clear that in their eyes it is not at all clear who decides what, Parliament, the Commission, the Council.  And it is true, as my fellow Members have said, that Parliament is working with a good degree of transparency, whereas how can we blame the citizens of Europe? Because one of the three institutions, the Council, has always worked behind closed doors, worked behind closed doors and behaves just as if it were playing a game of poker, covered cards.  The Council is therefore working in this way and we have no idea what position the players hold, no pardon, so the Member States. It is a pity that very important games are playing out on this table on that table for the future of the citizens of Europe itself. All this tramples on the principles of openness and transparency and undermines the right of citizens to have full knowledge of the decisions taken by their representatives. All this can only undermine the very idea of Europe.  I hope that this Europe has not been irreversibly disfigured, and I sincerely hope so.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start with the comment that it is not for the Commission to comment in detail on the internal procedures of the Council. The Commission has however always been committed to enhancing the transparency of the legislative process in general, which is a shared responsibility. The Commission came to office with a commitment to enhance transparency. For example, Commissioners, their cabinets and directors-general only meet with interest representatives who are in the transparency register. We have proposed to extend this principle the Parliament and Council and we still hope that the three institutions will all agree on this in order to make the transparency register mandatory for lobbyists. We are also publishing information on these meetings and on Commissioners’ mission expenses. We have adopted new rules on Commission expert groups with stronger transparency requirements and we have provided unprecedented levels of access to information on ongoing trade negotiations and also during the Brexit negotiations. Based on the Commission’s proposal, this Parliament and the Council agreed with us on new interinstitutional agreement on better law-making which includes a joint commitment to enhance the transparency of legislative procedures, including as appropriate trilateral negotiations and to improve communication to the public. As your report notes, work is continuing between the services of the three institutions in developing the joint legislative portal, which we together committed to set up. It will be a user-friendly way for non-specialists to access information about ongoing legislative proceedings. A lot of information is already available if you know where to look but this is not always easy to find for non-experts. This portal should change that. If either the Parliament or the Council wish to publish additional information compared to what is presently made public, this would be a logical place to do so.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: This item on the agenda has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 January 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Written. "Transparency in decision-making is one of the cornerstones of democracy. This is very important for public confidence. Citizens, the media and stakeholders must be able to ensure that national governments act on their public promises in the preparation of matters. Council preparatory meetings and most discussions take place in camera. Public access to documents is systematically restricted. Transparency requirements and democratic control will also be circumvented by preparing important decisions in informal contexts such as the Eurogroup and the Euro Summit. Secrecy increases suspicion, which is detrimental to the reputation of the EU as a whole. It also fuels rumors, fake news and conspiracy theories. The Council's action should be more transparent and meetings should be transparent. Transparency legislation should also apply to informal Council bodies. In addition, the minutes of meetings should record the positions of individual Member States on the matters to be dealt with. In practice, this would enable citizens and journalists to monitor national governments acting on public promises at meetings.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Azerbaijan, in particular the case of Mehman Huseynov (2019/2511(RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, also in Azerbaijan, who may, I hope, follow this debate! Yesterday, in the Internet newspaper Azeri Daily, I read an article in which I and the colleagues who worked on this resolution are accused of being involved in a large-scale plot to prepare a coup against the Government of Azerbaijan. I recommend that the journalists of this newspaper talk to us before they write anything like this. I also recommend, for example, to my elected colleagues from Azerbaijan in the EuroNest parliamentary assembly to talk to me. That is what I tried to do before we launched this resolution. Unfortunately, I did not succeed. My former colleague at EuroNest, Fuad Muradov, is now a minister in the government of Azerbaijan, and he knows very well that my concern in my work at EuroNest has always been to ensure good relations, reliable relations, especially between us MEPs. Why have we really put this urgency on the agenda? We are concerned about the fate of Mehman Hüseynov. Mehman Hüseynov has been on hunger strike since December last year, because he is threatened with being tried again before the end of his sentence, to which he was sentenced for two years, and now fears that he will be sentenced to five to seven more years before the end of his first prison sentence. This situation is not a one-off situation, but the Civil Society Forum in EuroNest has informed us that this pattern is now repeating itself for the fifth time. And this and our concerns for the welfare of Mehman Hüseynov have led us to put this urgency on the agenda. We appeal to the Azerbaijani Government with all the groups in this House: release Mehman Hüseynov! We appeal to the judges not to reopen such a staged case against him. Mehman has made a living investigating corruption in the Council of Europe. That is why he is now in prison. And he has not only dealt with problems in Azerbaijan, but also with problems of corrupt politicians, for example in Germany and Italy. That is another reason why it is right that the European Parliament should now stand up for his unconditional release.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: author. – Mr President, it seems like there are no more boundaries for President Aliyev in his war against his opponents. The message of the despot is clear: no one must dare to publicly highlight the extensive corruption and abuses by Azerbaijan’s rulers and officials.  The case of Mehman Huseynov is emblematic. The journalist and blogger has been repeatedly harassed by the police for years, tortured and jailed on fabricated charges. In addition, the new charges are clearly politically motivated. They are tailored to further silence a prominent human rights voice. As a matter of fact, instead of investigating the alleged mistreatment suffered by Mr Huseynov, he was accused of defamation of the same officials that tormented him. After all, what would you expect from a country that ranks 163rd out of 180 countries on the World Press Freedom Index? What do you expect from a country where independent journalists and bloggers are thrown in prison if they do not bend to harassment bribes, beatings and blackmail? The European Union is now negotiating a new agreement with Azerbaijan which should be based on the rule of law, human rights, good governance and democratic reforms. I believe this principle should not remain only on paper. The future agreement of Parliament to such an Act should not be given unless the situation changes radically.  Azerbaijan’s crackdown on dissidents must end immediately and the unconditional release of political prisoners must be a priority in EU—Azerbaijan relations. This is why I call on the Commission to use all its influence and pressure to ensure the Azerbaijani authorities drop the charges and release Mr Huseynov unconditionally, along with the ten other journalists jailed. If we fail on that, we will be giving up once again on our principles and values.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, it is nearly two years since Mehman Huseynov was sentenced to a two year jail sentence on a trumped up charge of slander. As a well-known blogger that sought to shed light on the alleged corruption of those in power there, there’s always been a strong suspicion that the case against him was politically motivated. With his release date fast approaching and the authorities now seeking to press further charges that could see him remain in prison for another five to seven years, those suspicions are fully justified. Far from being an isolated case there are claims that only this month there been five similar cases in which new charges are being brought against those whose sentences are about to end. None of this however should come as a great surprise given Azerbaijan’s terrible track record for press freedom, ranking 163 out of 180 countries according to the World Press Freedom Index. It is amongst the worst in the world in fact. I’m pleased that we have been able to raise his case today in this House, particularly given his vulnerable health as he continues a partial hunger strike. I strongly support the calls in this resolution for his immediate release and for the authorities to bring no further charges in Azerbaijan, which is an Eastern neighbourhood country with which the European Union enjoys good relations.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Author. – Mr President, in Azerbaijan corruption is no without any problem, it is an endemic problem, and those who dare to denounce it end up imprisoned or tortured. This is the situation we're talking about here. This is the situation of Mehman Heseynov, who serves a two-year sentence and faces new charges, so he may be imprisoned for another seven years. Prior to his arrest, in 2017, Heseynov launched the "Find Corrupt Officials" campaign, in which he exposed the corruption committed by Azerbaijan's ruling elite. This elite mounted a secret plot to pay European figures, buy luxury goods and launder money. According to the allegations, Azerbaijan's political dome, accused of systematic human rights abuses, widespread corruption and election-tailedness, bought European politicians and journalists to curb criticism of the president, silence human rights violations and promote a positive image of the country. It's what's called caviar diplomaphy. One of these European authorities was Pedro Agramunt, who had to resign from his post as President of the Council of Europe and as a member of his Parliamentary Assembly following this and other scandals. But because corruption seems to also be endemic in his party—the PP—he continues to serve as a senator even today in Spain. Corruption also permea in large natural resource extraction projects, but Azerbaijan is crucial as a source of resources for Europe in its longing to seek an alternative to Russia. That is why we have not spoken about this either in this Resolution.  Azerbaijan is the source of the South Caucasus pipeline and the BTC pipeline, 1,700 km of pipe carrying oil to the West. It was, by the way, the corruption of the BTC, promoted by British Petroleum ten years ago, that fueled the image-washing campaign in the Council of Europe that we were talking about earlier. We demand that any European participation in the South Caucasus corridor be cancelled. That the negotiations of the Association Agreement be suspended, since there is no willingness to respect the freedom of expression, association and assembly of its citizens. We recall that a few months ago this House approved the condition of the Association Agreement on the release of political prisoners, on the opening up of the civil society workspace. We're still waiting. We requested, as we did in 2017, an investigation by the competent authorities in the fight against fraud and money laundering of the so-called 'caviar diplomafia'. And of course, we urge the Spanish authorities to use all the mechanisms at their disposal to investigate the allegations against Senator Pedro Agramunt and force him to resign his senate seat. It seems, once again, that when it comes to the European Union's foreign policy towards its neighbours, the values and interests, which are deeply intertwined rather than mutually exclusive, (incomprehensible words) lead to real clear provisions and measures against Azerbaijan.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: author. – Mr President, it is actually quite sad that we’re here once again debating the deteriorating human rights situation in Azerbaijan under the leadership of President Aliyev and the vice-president, his wife. Human rights defenders and activists, such as Mehman Huseynov who are shedding light on corruption are being harassed, unlawfully detained and tortured. And although this crackdown on human rights, democracy and civil society is systematic, the European Commission signed a partnership agreement with Azerbaijan this summer. I think we have to question the issue of conditionality and how we can best use it now. Certainly any partnership agreement with any country cannot become a reason to, or an excuse to, avoid addressing the human rights violations in the strongest possible terms. In fact, and many colleagues have mentioned this, Azerbaijan is ranked 163rd among 180 countries in 2008 on the World Press Freedom Index. That is a shockingly low ranking and it is confirmed by the fact that 10 journalists are currently imprisoned, but there’s also a number of websites and blogs that are blocked in the country. In fact some of the country’s brightest minds have already left, because their freedom and safety was jeopardised and their families were intimidated. This is the kind of thing we previously saw with the cowardly leaking of videos and the fining of Khadija Ismayilova of EUR 23 000, which is almost 10 times the annual per capita income of the country, and shows the extent of pressure and the diversity of pressure on press and journalists, but also on opposition figures, civil society leaders and others. The overall situation concerning human rights and freedom is very dire: imprisonment, harassment, intimidation and fines. These are in direct violation of Azerbaijan’s obligations stemming from its signing of the European Convention of Human Rights and also the rulings of the European Court of Human Rights. So as we look to a new agreement between the EU and Azerbaijan, it is important that we confirm our commitment to the conditionality of this partnership agreement, depending on democratic reforms, respect for the rule of law, good governance and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. They must be at the core of the agreement and we should not brush over them. There are also conditions before the consent of this House can be given at a later stage. So in the meantime we should a look to a renewed partnership agreement and as these human rights defenders are being systematically harassed, we expect nothing less than the European Commission and the High Representative/Vice-President, Ms Mogherini to condemn the human rights violations in Azerbaijan in the strongest possible terms, and to join us in calling for the release of journalists, opposition figures and political prisoners alike.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: author. – Mr President, when we talk about human rights and the rule of law being the basis of our action, and our action towards third countries, namely through the agreements that we have negotiated – that we are negotiating with Azerbaijan – it’s not rhetoric. It’s up to people like you, Commissioner Malmström, like Federica Mogherini, to indeed deliver, to make sure it happens. It’s not just perfunctory and the case of Azerbaijan is a scandal, what has been going on and, as the case of Mehman Huseynov demonstrates – but we could mention many other activists such as Khadija Ismayilova, Ilgar Mammadov and Afgan Mukhtarli, who was kidnapped in Georgia and brought to Azerbaijan to be tortured in jail. And why? Because these brave people dared to expose the corruption on which is based this regime of Aliyev. It’s really horrendous that, despite all these principles, the people who are negotiating and were proposing to this Parliament to give its consent, in fact they do opposite. It’s a shame. We expect you to deliver on these principles and indeed make a sound evaluation of what the situation is and the situation is what has been described by my colleagues who spoke earlier. In the case of Mehman Huseynov, it shows the level of pressure and of torture that these people are being subjected to. This week, one of our colleagues, Norica Nicolai, distributed to all of us a letter that he eventually wrote – he was obviously forced to write – because if you read this letter it reminds me of the letters that people under the dictatorship in my country, under Salazar, and people in her country, under Ceaușescu, would write under duress to pretend that everything is alright, to try to prevent us from adopting the resolution that we are going to adopt today. What is even more atrocious, as was mentioned by my colleague Miguel Urbán Crespo, is indeed the corruption that it has been fomenting inside the European Union, as the case of the Azerbaijani Laundromat demonstrates, with politicians, even in this Parliament, as we saw in 2013, in the elections in Azerbaijan bought by this regime. We cannot allow it to go on. It’s not just about Azerbaijan, it’s not about supporting those who fight against corruption and for human rights and the rule of law in Azerbaijan, it’s about the EU.

name: Soraya POST
text: Author. – Dear Chairman, Distinguished Commissioner, at the outset I would like to thank my colleagues for the consultations carried out in detail regarding the case of Mehman Huseynov. As I am the shadow rapporteur of the European People's Party for the Azerbaijan report and now the EPP negotiator for this resolution, I consider that this resolution underlines the importance of the issue of bilateral relations between the European Union and Azerbaijan.  We need to attach great importance to the new Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Azerbaijan, and respect for the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms must be at the heart of the new agreement.  Mehmet Huseynov is an anti-corruption blogger and director of the Institute for Freedom and Security, sentenced to two years in prison for publicly complaining about his experience with police and poor treatment and torture in law enforcement after he criticised public officials by releasing data on their undeclared wealth. Two months before his release, for allegedly assaulting a prison guard, he is facing an extension of his sentence to an additional 5 to 7 years. The resolution calls for the immediate release of Mr. Huseynov and the provision of professional medical assistance, stressing the importance of democratizing society and protecting human rights. The aim is to send a message that the European Union does not intend to sever ties and co-operation with Azerbaijan, but aims, as a show of support, to help find solutions and models in achieving the transformation of Azerbaijan into a democratic and tolerant society.  The European Union is currently the only one with the authority to help the country strengthen these rights through dialogue. I hereby call for the release of all prisoners of conscience. Europe must stick to the principle on which it is founded, which is freedom of thought and speech in the countries with which it cooperates. In particular, I do not list Azerbaijan here, but all third countries with which Europe cooperates without selectively applying the same principles, both by the European Union and this Parliament. This right, which is the basis of the declaration of human rights, must not be used selectively. This resolution is good in that it also warns about Azerbaijan's position in freedom of expression, which, unfortunately, is the 163rd country out of 183 countries. Tragic. The cases of using funds to buy influence in politicians, journalists and those who can create public opinion in Europe and in political decision-making power centres with their former political connections, this is worrying. It's got to stop. I expect urgent assistance to Huseynov, his release and adequate medical attention. The release, too, of all political prisoners and prisoners of conscience because it is inadmissible in the 21st century. Friendships with partner countries must be built on mutual values. Ours are: protecting the weakest and freedom of speech. That, Mr. Chairman and Esteemed Commissioner, is not traded with that. Rights are not traded, the protection of the weakest must be the cornerstone of European foreign policy and the basis on which we will build ties with all third countries, regardless of what area they come from. That's what we have to stand for in this Parliament and I will fight for that as long as I am an MP.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I strongly demand the release of Mehman Hüsejnov, who is on hunger strike against lawlessness in Azerbaijan. Along with him in Azerbaijani prisons, many other prisoners suffer from conscience. For all of them, I recall the case of Afghan Muchtarlí abducted by the secret services from neighboring Georgia. Baku's sanctions against critics of the regime are not limited to the territory of their own country. I draw attention to the expansion of the azerbaijani regime's influence beyond its borders. The export of influence and coercion takes place in different ways. For example, by kidnapping, as in the case of Muchtarlí. Another way of persecuting opponents of the regime is to abuse Interpol to extradite those who have fled the regime and seek asylum and protection outside their home.  Abuses of Interpol by China or Russia are becoming more frequent. Interpol resists attempts to extradite political opponents. It relies on Article 3 of its own constitution, which says interpol does not meddle in political affairs. Interpol relied on this article when it rejected baku's request to arrest three MEPs some time ago. Let us look for ways to prevent the persecution of freedom of speech, ideas and religion in Azerbaijan. One way could be to support non-governmental European organisations dealing with Azerbaijan.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this is about the third urgency resolution we have had on human rights abuses in Azerbaijan during this mandate. It is really time for the Government of Azerbaijan to take our demands seriously. I demand the immediate and unconditional release of Mehman Huseynov and all other human rights defenders like lawyers, youth activists, political opponents, anti-corruption activists, independent journalists and bloggers in Azerbaijan. These people have been arrested and are being tortured and imprisoned for exercising their freedom of expression and for criticising their Government. That is not a crime. To the Azeri officials, I would like to say that it is a right. Some of these people are serving prison sentences for ten years just because they have investigated, or protested against, corruption in the Government.  The EU cannot stay silent while the media and free speech is being repressed in Azerbaijan. We cannot accept the random arrest, harassment, torture and ill treatment of LGBTI people, human rights defenders and political prisoners. If these demands are not met, the EU should take measures such as sanctions against the responsible Azeri officials. The European Commission and financial bodies should suspend all financing for Azerbaijan state structures, enterprises and joint ventures.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, in my capacity as Chair of the delegation for relations with the South Caucasus, we have seen a marked change in our relations with Azerbaijan. Month after month, year after year, the progress that has been made in ensuring that a strong partnership between the EU and Azerbaijan emerges can be measured in leaps and bounds. The European Union as a champion of democracy, human rights and free speech across the globe should not, and must not ever, turn a blind eye to the mistreatment of any individual by any government. No matter how exciting and no matter how extensive the progress in international agreements may be, we must not abandon the individuals they are designed to benefit. With these individuals in mind, there is much in the resolution that is in front of us today that our Parliament must reinforce in its message by calling on the Commission, on the European External Action Service to seek, and indeed Azerbaijan to provide, adequate protections for those accused of these crimes, guarantees of medical assistance, access to legal counsel. Family visits must be found as a priority for all individuals listed in this resolution. Indeed, the strong relationship that we have built with Azerbaijan has already paid dividends here, and the granting of access to the EU delegation to visit Mr Huseynov is a positive precursor to resolving the situations flagged in this resolution. Finally, our relations must always reflect our values, but equally they must always have respect for all of our partners.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Mr President, in my capacity as Parliament's rapporteur for Azerbaijan, I would like to make the following points: it is true, we are in the presence of the third resolution which signals slippages in terms of human rights, but, as Mr Karim said, relations between the European Union and Azerbaijan have evolved in a positive way. We are preparing to conclude this partnership agreement and I think it is a good opportunity to have a very serious discussion about the effect of the European Parliament's actions on third countries. When we have all worked in good faith, in an attempt to have constructive dialogues with the authorities, we have had and achieved the success of releasing a man, please remember, a prominent political prisoner – I mean Mr Mammadov – as a result of our efforts, but done in a non-confrontational manner, in a decent manner. Also in the same year, last year, through the same steps of the European Parliament, carried out in a diplomacy and in a coherent dialogue, we succeeded and released 146 people. I think it is very important that this kind of action continues. Mr Huseynov: We have seen very clearly how these allegations have started and we have seen the approach of Free Europe radio. At the same time, I received from Baku – because I confess that I have asked for explanations in connection with this incident – an official statement by the Department of Control of the Administration of Prisons, in which I was told that, in an ambush, one of the inspectors was assaulted and all those involved in this ambush were sanctioned. We have also seen that he has come out of a hunger strike, which contradicts a number of allegations. I believe, ladies and gentlemen, that when we draft a resolution on human rights in a third state of the European Union, we must, first of all, document ourselves very clearly, listen to all parties, because that means democratic spirit, and not privilege a source of information, because there is a risk, in a world where misinformation and fake news are the rule , that this rule should also apply to us and risk diplomatic steps that may have serious consequences. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: blue-card question. – Ms Nicolai do you agree that it is absolutely unacceptable that the regime in Azerbaijan buys European politicians such as Mr Pedro Agramunt, who is now a senator in Spain, without any investigation into this ongoing corruption? Do you agree that it is tremendously damning to the credibility of European politicians and European action if politicians allow themselves to be bought by the regime such as that of President Aliyev?

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Thank you, Ana. I absolutely agree with you. I do not know what the situation of the Spanish politician is. This is the first time I've known this. I hope that things are clarified and that we are not only in the presence of allegations about the behaviour of politicians, but it is clear: it is unacceptable and we need to look objectively. But at the same time, please understand my constructive approach. I believe that it is good for these people to be free, not to continue to be in prison and subjected to abuse, because in this way we, as the European Parliament, are proving that we have done something concretely for the citizens.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, this very important and proud South Caucasian nation celebrated one hundred years of its short independence less than a year ago. What happened was that, in the flanks of this ceremony four organisers of an independent independence rally were detained. Is this a republic that is newly created and wants to become an important player in the international community and have ever—closer ties to the European Union? Is this a country that, as a republic, is also entitled to protect the freedoms and rights of its citizens? This doesn’t always seem to be the case to me. I feel that we have a very special relationship with this country because our own grandmother was born in Baku 1916. She will be 103 years old in January and she tells wonderful stories about her childhood and about Azerbaijan. We have to be aware that, at the same time as the EU is strengthening its contractual relationship with Azerbaijan, Azerbaijan is unfortunately turning away from its international commitments in the Council of Europe and the OSCE. It is not in vain that the Commissioner for Human Rights of the Council of Europe and the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media are seriously concerned about the situation at the moment, notably about Mr Huseynov’s situation.  As the European Parliament, we really must call on the Commission and the External Action Service to do their utmost: if the Azerbaijani Government wants to have an ever—closer relationship with the EU, they must, unconditionally and immediately, free the political prisoners, including Mr Mehman Huseynov.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, in our sittings on Thursday morning, say of good conscience, you mention the case of journalist Mehman Huseynov. He has just been sentenced to two years' imprisonment for denouncing Aliyev's authoritarian regime. Yes, this regime is autocratic, but what has the European Union done with regard to this regime?  I would like to recall that, on 16 November 2016, the Council gave the Commission a mandate to negotiate a comprehensive agreement with Azerbaijan. On 7 February 2017, negotiations began after President Aliyev's visit to Brussels. On 11 January 2018, new partnership priorities were adopted, including plans to relax the visa regime.  We know that the leaders of the European Union have only one obsession: to drag European nations and peoples into a new cold war against Russia. In doing so, as always, the small-memberists of the globalist cenacles policy aim to fragment the European continent. To do so, they do not hesitate to forge, as I have just mentioned, ever closer relations with the Baku regime.  We know that a pipeline is currently under construction between Azerbaijan and the Member States of the European Union, whereas our security of hydrocarbon supply should instead go through agreements with Russia. For the European Union, a lecturer, the smell of hydrocarbons trumps human rights. I would like to know what our colleague Norica Nicolai, rapporteur of the European Parliament's report on this new European agreement with Azerbaijan, thinks of this matter. According to the French daily Libération, she refused to comment on another previous case of human rights violations in Azerbaijan, that of Yunis Safarov, by referring to an article by the Azerbaijani News Agency, which is, of course, nothing but an unofficial body of the regime. What do the members of the ALDE group think, especially when they are willing to give us, usually always, lessons in democracy? For our part, let us not forget the martyrdom of the Armenian people of Nagorno-Karabakh caused by the Baku regime. For us, the true partner and friend of the European peoples in the Caucasus is the Armenian people. So let us go beyond and go beyond the stage of good conscience and put an end to this rapprochement with this regime.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Mr President, along with endemic corruption, human rights abuses constitute a sad reality in Azerbaijan. According to Amnesty International, there are currently more than 100 political prisoners in the Southern Caucasus country, where the regime also holds a tight grip over the media. According to the brother of the imprisoned blogger and human rights activist on hunger strike, ‘all well—known human rights defenders and journalists spend at least one or two years in prison’. This practice is compounded by a common trend whereby Azeri authorities press new charges against political prisoners whose prison sentences are ending. We know that this is the fifth such case in recent months alone. Azerbaijan has long tried to shield itself from Western criticism by using its strategic position as a regional ally in the war against terrorism as well as an important country for Europe in its quest to reduce its dependency on Russian gas. But it is also known that it uses lavish gifts and foreign trips for Western officials in an attempt to tone down criticism against the regime. The EU should give a clear signal that it takes the rule of law, good governance and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in Azerbaijan seriously and should place these issues at the heart of the new EU—Azerbaijan agreement. At present, it is vital that we ask for Mr Huseynov to be immediately and unconditionally released and that Azerbaijani authorities drop all new charges against him. We must also clearly call for the immediate and unconditional release from jail of all political prisoners, journalists, human rights defenders and other civil society activists.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, from the outset I want to say that the motion was necessary. It is a warning to the State of Azerbaijan about deviations from respect for the principles of human rights and others. At the same time, I would like to mention the importance of maintaining dialogue with Azerbaijan, not only in the areas of human rights violations, but also in areas such as: anti-terrorism, regional stability, combating manipulation. The motion, in fact, seeks to draw attention to the concrete cases of deviations from the democratic principles to which Azerbaijan has committed itself as a member of the Council of Europe. We could also see that there are concerns from OECD representatives, from media representatives. We must say that Azerbaijan, as a member of the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly, has obligations. I am part of the Euronest Assembly and I know what is required of all eastern Partnership countries. The new Presidency of the European Council aims to develop the Eastern Partnership, but for this, all the states that are part of this partnership must understand the importance of appropriating the requirements of today's motion. It is a balanced motion, the text of the resolution and the good things that have happened: the release in recent years of several personalities, human rights defenders, journalists, activists. I believe very much that Azerbaijan's road must be European, but for this, obviously, the representatives of the State – and I stress, the representatives of the State, because it is not the citizens there who have any fault – they must cooperate and respect the obligations of the European Convention on Human Rights. Last year there was a meeting, the Parliamentary Cooperation Committee in Baku, and these topics were discussed. I believe that the EU-Azerbaijan agreement started in 1996 must continue.

name: Julie WARD
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am not going along with the reasoning of some of our colleagues here who are trying to put violations of universal human rights into perspective or to gloss over it on the grounds that there has been a great deal of progress, or progress. Look, Azerbaijan is becoming the world's court supplier of persecuted bloggers. That is an unenviable export product, but that seems to be the least concern of President Aliyev. About 150 political opponents and journalists are behind bars. Today we call for the release of a young activist. Mehman Huseynov has a critical pen and, with his much-discussed contributions via social media, holds up a mirror to the regime. It offers an anything but beautiful image. For as the people of Azerbaijan grapple with economic decline and poverty, the political elite revels around President Aliyev. The price Mehman pays for his journalistic work is very high. On trumped-up charges, he's been locked up for nearly two years. He's due out in March. The fact that this is not to the liking of that regime is apparent from new charges that could lead to additional imprisonment of up to seven years. It is important to strengthen the EU-Azerbaijan relationship. But this cannot be done without drawing extra attention to the fundamental importance of human and civil rights, free media, and so on.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, a free and vibrant press is a necessary component of any properly functioning democracy. When politicians are able to act without the scrutiny of such an important part of public life, a distance grows between the politicians and the people that they represent. Corruption can inherently follow.  Azerbaijan’s record in this area is poor. They are ranked 163rd in the World Press Freedom Index. Mehman Huseynov’s  case is a saddening humaniser of what that statistic means in reality for those that attempt to lift the lid on corruption in Azerbaijan and open up politics to its people. In prison for nothing more than picturing luxury houses alleged to have been gained through corruption, Reporters Without Borders are warning he could die in prison as he goes on hunger strike on trumped up charges that continue to be brought up against him. Many more have joined this hunger strike.  It is time for the politicians to listen to the people and to begin to address the failures in democracy and to allow the development of a proper true free press for this country.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I too condemn the current situation in Azerbaijan regarding the government’s violation of fundamental rights and freedoms of the press. The enforcement of censorship prohibiting criticism of the government is contrary to these freedoms and must be condemned. I also denounce the fact that political activists and journalists have repeatedly found themselves faced with new charges as they near the end of their prison sentences in a ploy to detain them for longer.  Azerbaijan’s participation in the EU’s Eastern Partnership and the commitments made in its membership of the Council of Europe are undermined by the actions of the Azerbaijani authorities. I therefore call on the Azerbaijani Government to fulfil its international obligations and comply with the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights in guaranteeing these rights and releasing those wrongly imprisoned, particularly Mr Huseynov, who has been referred to already by other speakers, and who has been on dry hunger strike since December 2018 in protest. The practice of selective criminal prosecution must be ended and the censorship rules prohibiting criticism of the government removed. There is no place for such measures in a country that has committed itself to the rule of law, democracy and the protection of human rights, and wants to have closer relations with the European Union.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Mr President, the EU’s position on Azerbaijan needs to be much firmer. Civil society is operating in an extremely hostile environment. NGOs are closing down and independent voices are either imprisoned or forced to go into exile. Mehman is now on his 23rd day of hunger strike and his situation is very worrying. Having been subjected to torture several times, he is in a serious situation.  Over the past few months, there has been a worrying increase in the number of hunger strikes around the world: Leyla Güven, in Kurdistan and Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and Narges Mohammadi in Iran, for instance. All are forced to take desperate measures.  High Representative, the urgency of the situation calls on you to make a public statement and urge the Azerbaijani authorities to immediately and unconditionally release Mehman. The EU must name and shame any country that blatantly violates its human rights obligations, regardless of the economic ties it might share with the country. I also call on the EU and the Member States to impose sanctions, not only on the President, but also on its ministers who, until now, have not been targeted.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Mr President, Mehman Huseynov, blogger and director of the Institute for Reporters’ Freedom and Safety was jailed due to criticism of his country’s regime and criminal justice system. Unfortunately this is not an isolated case. The authoritarian Government of Azerbaijan has virtually closed space for independent anti-corruption activism, critical journalism and opposition political activities, through prosecution, arbitrary arrests and unjust convictions. This is not the first time we pass a resolution on Azerbaijan in this House, and I believe it is time to say ‘enough is enough’. It is now time for us to demand the government of Azerbaijan to end its persecution of civil society, to allow independent media to operate within the country and immediately to release Mr Huseynov and all other political prisoners and activists. The EU has to take a clear stance here and stick to the principle of freedom of speech and respect for civil liberties, which stand at the very foundations of the EU itself. Human rights, Madam Commissioner, are not to be bargained and until this oppression and violation stops the EU must suspend all financial aid to the oppressive regime of Azerbaijan.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to join all my colleagues here in calling for tough action against Azerbaijan in the case of the imprisoned Mr Hüsejnov.  But as a former Minister of Justice, I also want to add that Azerbaijan needs to be criticised in a broader context. And on top of the way the rule of law in this country is not working, I would like to add that in 2017 there was a reform of the legal professions in Azerbaijan, which prevented nine out of ten lawyers from carrying out the legal profession. More or less independent advocacy is not working in Azerbaijan, which is extremely important, and political prisoners do not have legal representation in the courts. We should also perceive this, because the rule of law includes not only independent courts, but also independent advocacy of the state, which also defends clients against state power. Unfortunately, this is not the case in this country, so please, when discussing with Azerbaijani leaders, let us also criticise the 2017 reform, which is tearing down independent advocacy.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this possibility to discuss again the human rights situation in Azerbaijan. We have been following very closely, like you all have, this situation and the recent developments in the case of Mehman Huseynov. This came to our attention already in 2017. We made a statement then, and let me use this opportunity to tell you what we have been doing in recent days.  Following the demarche by the delegation of the European Union in Baku, and thanks to cooperation by the Azerbaijan authorities, the EU delegation, together with five Member States missions, visited Mr Huseynov in prison. The visit at the end of last week allowed us to establish that his life was not at immediate risk. He is receiving medical care and he has stopped his hunger strike.  Nevertheless, we do believe, like you, that the new charges against him for allegedly assaulting prison staff lack credibility and should be dropped. We are aware, as some of you raised, of other hunger strikes by activists. We are following up here with contacts with a lawyer and the prison services and I know that they had been visited by the Red Cross.  Over the past years the EU has placed considerable emphasis on the human rights situation in Azerbaijan. We do so in our political dialogue with the country, including high—level meetings at the EU Azerbaijan Subcommittee on Justice Affairs and Human Rights. The joint partnership priorities, as agreed in July last year, underscore that the rule of law and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms are key in our relationship. The new EU—Azerbaijan agreement currently being negotiated will have democratic reforms, the rule of law, good governance and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms at its core.  We remain all too aware of the considerable challenges relating to the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms in Azerbaijan. We believe that we should work on addressing them through dialogue, including through the negotiations on the new agreement. We need to have channels of communication to build mutual trust and engagement to effectively pursue our values and interests in Azerbaijan. While pursuing our engagement with the authorities, we are continuing to work closely with civil society organisations, independent media and human rights defenders to follow up on their concerns. We will continue to raise the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms in all our dialogues and most notably during the upcoming meeting on justice affairs and human rights in Baku on 5 February. We will closely follow the developments in the case of Mehman Huseynov and other human rights defenders and journalists, including, for instance, Khadija İsmayilova, and will continue, of course, a close dialogue with all of you on this issues.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Urmas PAET
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Sudan (2019/2512(RSP)).

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: author. – Mr President, with inflation rates of 122% and the government cutting fuel and food subsidies, the mass protests seen across Sudan during the past few weeks are of little surprise. It’s clear that what began as a manifestation of protest against bread queues and a wider cost of living concern, has now morphed into a broader anti—government, anti—regime movement with support across the oppositional divide. Furthermore, as President Omar al—Bashir looks to abolish presidential term limits in a bid to extend his already 30—year grip on power, we have witnessed an increasingly brutal response from the government in Khartoum to the continuing protests. That response has already resulted in up to 40 civilians losing their lives – the government itself has admitted to a figure of 24 – and some 2 000 to 3 000 people being arrested and detained. It’s clearly time for al—Bashir to relinquish power, being a man that possesses the dubious title of being the only current head of state anywhere in the world with two outstanding arrest warrants issued against him by the International Criminal Court. As the protests continue, we must remain vigilant of further escalation, particularly given the security challenges that already are present in that region of Africa.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: Author. Mr President, we have already adopted a number of resolutions on Sudan. The last one, in March 2018, concerned the arrest of Salih Mahmoud Osman, our 2007 Sakharov Prize winner, who was again arrested, apparently by the NISS, the sad Sudanese security service. His relatives fear for his health, not least because he is diabetic. One of many, unfortunately, once again. Human rights organizations say at least 2,000 people have been arrested since 19 December, dozens of people have been killed, not to mention torture. Since September 2013, protests have been taking place on a regular basis, mainly in Khartoum. Until now, they have been based on the economic crisis, following the loss of oil resources after the partition of Sudan, with record inflation - we are indeed talking about a rate of more than 120%, the second in the world - and, as a result, a steady increase in the prices of basic necessities in a country in a situation of shortage. Not to mention a budget of 70% for military spending, to the detriment of the rest, including health and education.  In December, after the tripling of the price of bread, the first demonstrations began outside the capital and spread across the country like wildfire, including in Darfur, where the ex-janjawid and the repression that goes with it still reign. Very quickly, the watchwords took a political turn. "Freedom, peace and justice" demand the protesters, as well as the end of the regime. Omar al-Bashir is not at all provocative and actually wants to change the constitution to represent himself, despite having been in power for 29 years, under several mandates of the International Criminal Court. The crackdown is all over the place: human rights defenders, academics, students, journalists, opposition leaders, including those of the People's Congress Party and the Sudanese Communist Party, which dared to lend its premises for a meeting of all stakeholders in the demonstrations. The Association of Sudanese Professionals has just called for a week of uprisings, culminating today in Khartoum and in major cities: a great march for peace and change. Here we have repeatedly denounced the agreements linking the European Union and Sudan through migration policies or the fight against terrorism. How can we cooperate with the law enforcement authorities in that country, including asking them to come here and identify their nationals in detention centres, or deliver equipment that can be used against the Sudanese population, including Darfur. All European funding needs to be reviewed to stop this hypocrisy.  Finally, on behalf of the GUE/NGL, I want to express my total solidarity with those who will demonstrate today in the streets of Sudan at the risk of their lives.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I was going to divide my speech into three parts. The first: peaceful protests must be allowed. It is natural and highly understandable that protests should spread when governments drastically increase the price of basic food and when the economic situation in the country deteriorates due to poor governance. In this case, the protests have spread from the countryside into the capital Khartoum. It must also be allowed to protest in order for President Omar al-Bashir, who has been in power for 29 years, to bring forward a successor. International human rights organisations in the country report 45 deaths so far. These are people who have protested and been killed by police. The second issue is the methods of the security services. It is totally unacceptable that such excessive force, against people who protest and against political opponents, should be used by sudan's security service, NISS. The mandate and methods of the NISS must, of course, comply with international standards, and that is not the case today. International standards of arrest should, of course, also be followed by the NISS. It is reported, for example, that niss used live ammunition against unarmed people and that torture is reported to have occurred in the country's prisons. It can never be accepted, not in any country.  The third is that the electoral calendar should be respected. According to the country's constitution, the incumbent president cannot run for president in 2020. But, as in so many other countries, the President is now trying to amend the Constitution so that he can stand anyway in the 2020 elections, and to his aid he has a group of legal experts close to him. Twenty-two political parties in opposition to the incumbent president have called for power to be taken over by a transitional government and for a date for democratic elections to be immediately called. Since I have time to take over, I also raise a fourth question. This resolution is, of course, based on current and unacceptable events in Sudan, but if we take a look and think a little more about the situation in Sudan, it is impossible for me as a Green not to see how the climate impact and its consequences have had a devastating impact on development for a couple of decades. When the conditions for cultivation deteriorate and when people are forced to flee their lands, tensions and therefore conflicts increase, and Sudan is a clear example of this.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: author. – Mr President, in spite of weeks of anti-government protests in Sudan and calls for the resignation of Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir, the ruling party in Sudan has nominated Bashir for a new term in the elections that are to be held in 2020. The ruling party National Congress Party (NCP) has stated that the country’s leadership will only be changed through elections. That remains to be seen. But the fact is that Bashir is the only sitting head of state wanted by the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity and war crimes, genocide and ethnic cleansing in Darfur. Yet he remains free to continue his crimes, and he is welcomed by so many states with open arms – states like China, India, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and many others that continue to allow Bashir into their countries, welcome him and support him, instead of arresting him. It is also their inaction that enables Bashir to continue his crimes with impunity, attacking civilians. This is also why we are witnessing Bashir’s latest actions, whereby at least 37 people have lost their lives, more than 800 have been arrested, and there is ongoing violence and oppression by the authorities. Mass arrests and killings – targeting activists, human rights defenders, lawyers, doctors, teachers – Bashir and his accomplices must face charges. Those responsible for the crimes of the past in Sudan, as well as those committed during the latest protests must be brought to justice. It is time for Sudan to focus on ending the repression of human rights and resolve the economic crisis and start healing society.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Auteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Sudan, one of africa's largest countries, has returned to the centre of our attention.  Recent reports from Sudan have been very bad. While much of the world was busy celebrating at the end of the year, Sudanese poured into the streets and squares, protesting the decline in purchasing power. At the origin of the protest were the price increases first of petrol, then of bread whose price has tripled by decree. There have been protests in the country, which jeopardise the very fragile social balance achieved and unfortunately confirm the precariousness of people's lives. The economic situation is not favourable for the country, despite the fact that it has many resources.  Sudan is moving forward, alternating periods of relative calm with other particularly hard times for citizens, affected by hunger and the harmful effects of the government, which often degenerate into social conflicts with a strong repressive value, on the part of the security forces. Not only the sudanese citizens who are contesting the riots, but also the opposition, are paying the price for the unrest. In this way, Sudan confirms the sad reality of political repression of freedom of expression, which is the source of legitimate claims by exasperated citizens.  We must always remind the Government of Khartoum that it is up to it to ensure that its country's development is given priority and speed. It is only through the development of economic activities in the country and the installation of a healthy political climate that protest movements can be appeased. In this respect, it is important to stress the role of the political dialogue that we would like to see practised, especially after the formation of the new coalition of opposition parties.  The Sakharov Prize winner, Salih Mahmoud Osman, and all the free thinkers, professors at Khartoum University, journalists and human rights defenders, must therefore be released for a more democratic Sudan.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: author. – Mr President, Sudan has now been independent for 63 years. Almost 30 years ago, Colonel Omar al—Bashir came to power, suspended political parties and introduced an Islamic legal code at the national level and appointed himself President in 1993.
