So, Sudan became a one party state under the National Congress Party. Later in the 1990s, Sudan was listed as a state sponsor of terrorism by several countries. Six years ago, President al—Bashir promised not to seek re-election, but ran again in 2015, while the opposition boycotted the elections. As for press freedom, Sudan ranks as one of the last ones, taking the 174th position on the list of 180 countries. Last December, massive demonstrations erupted, first as a protest against price increases but then expanded as a broadly based movement against the authoritarian regime calling for the President al—Bashir to resign. He has now been in power, as said, almost 30 years. The current death toll has reached almost 50, with hundreds of people arrested and tortured – especially Sakharov Prize winner Salih Mahmoud Osman, he’s a human rights lawyer, who was once again arrested only nine days ago. His whereabouts are unknown.  Furthermore, Sudan is classified as the fourth-worst country to be a Christian in last year’s watch list by Open Doors International. We condemn state-endorsed persecution of Christians and the closing and demolition of churches. Muslims who convert to Christianity faced the death penalty for apostasy. One very serious fact to keep in mind, which was mentioned just a few minutes ago, is that al–Bashir is the only incumbent head of state wanted by the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity, war crimes and ethnic cleansing in the Darfur region. He should be seen and treated as an international pariah.  The European Parliament strongly condemns excessive use of force against popular protests and asks for the immediate release of Salih Mahmoud Osman and all human rights defenders, journalists and protesters. We ask to end restrictions on access to the internet and provide for freedom of press. We call on the Commission and the High Representative to publicly condemn the intolerable situation in Sudan, and to use all means to convince the government there to end the ongoing violence, to stop mass arrests and killings. We also call for an EU-wide ban on exports, update and maintenance of any form of security equipment, which is being used for internal repression, including Internet surveillance technology. We ask the EU and Member States to strengthen financial support for human rights defenders and civil society organisations under the European Development Fund.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Sudan would be a beautiful country if there was no dictatorship in that country. These are the words classics interpreted on this earth. This is not the first time we have been in this room. This country is really full of different injustices and I would have to repeat each of these injustices and I would be here a long time to mention them.  Religious freedom in this country is a total utopia. That there is hundreds, perhaps thousands, of evidence that prisoners are being tortured: we recently spoke in the European Parliament about the case of Czech aid worker Petr Yašek, who was in prison for a year. His narrative of how prisoners who are non-Constelling are subjected to so-called waterboarding and other torture methods is absolutely scandalous, and I think that we, as the European Union, must point these things out.  In a number of countries, it is through dialogue with civil society and the support of humanitarian workers that we have managed to establish the situation that the climate in these countries has really begun to change gradually in society. Unfortunately, Sudan is one of the cases where we are failing, and I think today is the time for the High Representative of the European Union to send a clear message to Sudan that the European Union will never tolerate the injustice that is being persuased against ordinary citizens, that the European Union will never tolerate any politician and representative of a country that systematically violates human rights and kills its citizens that the European Union will never support the fact that many of the sudanese regime's socialites have money in other countries.  I think that we should also make it quite clear to other countries that Sudan is the worst dictatorship in Africa, which is still in power, and whoever supports it is no partner for the European Union.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, since December last year, peaceful demonstrations have taken place on the streets of several cities in Sudan, which have spread throughout the country, including the capital Khartoum, with citizens legitimately protesting against rising prices, food shortages and fuel shortages. National security forces intervened, using excessive force, to disperse unarmed protesters. The right to freedom of peaceful assembly is an essential element of democracy. The government of Sudan has a duty to respond with solutions to the legitimate grievances of the Sudanese people and not to resort to violence, which has led to the killing of 40 people, including children. Arbitrary arrests of an unknown number of protesters, including students and political activists, are actions that must stop. The Sudanese authorities must release those prisoners, carry out impartial investigations and the guilty persons be brought to justice and ensure that national security forces respond to protests in accordance with the country's international human rights obligations. The lack of access of lawyers and members of the prisoners' family, as well as the use of torture and other forms of ill-treatment against prisoners, give rise to serious concerns about their safety. We call on the Government of Sudan to put an end to any kind of harassment, violence, including at the administrative and judicial level, against all human rights lawyers and defenders and to guarantee the right to a fair trial.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, last week The Economist published its annual "Democracy Index". Sudan dangles as an authoritarian state at the very bottom of that ranking. The country does not yet look remotely like a democracy. There is no functioning, caring government, civil liberties are virtually non-existent. The international community has written countless reports on human rights in the country and very little is changing. What still works is the violent security forces and the militias of dictator Al-Bashir. They are taking a sharp line at civilians taking to the streets in response to hunger, economic uncertainty and the crackdown on the regime in Khartoum. Recent demonstrations have left dozens dead and hundreds injured. Many human rights activists, journalists and members of the opposition are imprisoned. Known methods of a regime that has fear of the street and a fear that is justified. Whether we protest outside or starve indoors, we die anyway, it resonates in the streets. This Parliament must take sides and express its support for the activists, for the increasingly mobilising civil society, for the people of Sudan, who suffer from the regime of someone who belongs behind bars because of human rights violations. You don't build a better society with Mr Al-Bashir.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the people want the regime to fall, it is the song of protest that resounds on the streets of Khartoum, amid the rumble of gunfire and the metallic noise that accompanies tear gas.  Thousands of Sudanese citizens took to the streets on 19 December to demand real change for their country, starting with the resignation of their president. From that moment only chaos. Not only police forces, but also intelligence services and paramilitary teams, brutally unleashed against demonstrators and ordinary citizens. The death toll is tragic: 45 dead, 816 people arrested in just three weeks.  All this to defend a single man, a bloodthirsty dictator, who has been in power for over thirty years, Omar al-Bashir. What is more, this man, whose head is on an arrest warrant for genocide and crimes against humanity in Darfur, is trying to amend the Constitution to remove any remaining limits on his mandate, in view of the next elections in 2020.  We call on the Sudanese Government to unconditionally release all the demonstrators, Salih Osman, the 2007 Sakharov Prize winner, and the 23 young university students of Darfur origin, who were arrested on 23 December. We call on the High Representative, the whole Union, to make real use of all forms of economic, commercial and political pressure to exert the right pressure to stop this disgraceful massacre.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, a 2012 post in The Rule of the Game, a review of the pseudo-philosopher going to war well known to the French Bernard-Henri Lévy, stated without shame that the ideas of the National Front were those applied in Sudan. Let me be a bit provocative and compare the news. According to press reports, Sudanese authorities have arrested 800 people in connection with recent anti-government protests. That's less than the 5,000 yellow vests taken into custody in France since the start of the protest against President Macron's arrogance. According to the death toll, between 20 and 40 people died in Sudan. In France, the media reported that about 100 protesters were seriously injured. Minister Castaner's repression also knows how to be effective. While Sudan applies Sharia law and persecutes Christians, in Europe Islamists are gaining ground.  So I sometimes wonder, ladies and gentlemen, about moral lessons. It is time for Parliament to first look at what is happening under its nose before dealing with human rights on other continents.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Sudan's protests have been getting bloody for nearly a month and the situation in the country is becoming increasingly tense. Therefore, we cannot idly watch bloodshed and human rights violations. The vast majority of Sudanese live in extreme poverty, living on the equivalent of less than a dollar a day, so it is understandable that rising prices and food shortages have taken Sudanese to the streets. It is also understood that the Sudanese do not want to agree to constitutional changes that would allow President Bashir - accused by the International Criminal Court of crimes against humanity, war crimes and genocide - to stay in power at the end of this term.  I therefore believe that it is the duty of the European Union to demand that the Sudanese authorities stop using force in peaceful demonstrations, release wrongly arrested human rights defenders, journalists and opposition representatives, and stop persecuting Christians and representatives of other religions. Information on restrictions on freedom of expression, in particular restrictions on internet access and censorship of the press, is also very worrying. I am therefore in favour of an EU ban on the export to Sudan of all kinds of equipment that could be used for this purpose.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, last week, Marwa Elhaj, a Sudanese journalist living in Liverpool in my constituency, contacted me because of her concerns about the situation in her country. She tells me that the civil population faces unprecedented levels of violence in the margins of the protests against al—Bashir’s oppressive regime, including random shooting. She has documentary evidence. I’m particularly concerned by the situation of human rights defender and blogger Yasir Elsir Ali, who was shot by a sniper in Khartoum at the end of December and spent 10 days in intensive care. Two days later he was abducted from his home by Sudanese security forces and he is now being held incommunicado in inhumane conditions. I’m very concerned for his health and well—being and I call on the Sudanese authorities to immediately release him and ensure he is given appropriate medical care abroad. The authorities must also inform his family and lawyer of his place of detention and allow them immediate access to him. His case is very worrying and Sudanese human rights organisations are gravely concerned, as are we. High Representative, please take all the necessary steps to urge Sudanese authorities to immediately release him. Meanwhile, I want to thank the people of Liverpool for standing with the Sudanese community in these difficult times. We will never surrender to Theresa May’s hostile environment regarding refugees, asylum seekers and migrants.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, once again we are discussing the deteriorating situation in Sudan in respect of fundamental freedoms. Popular unrest in response to austerity measures has evolved into anti-government movement. The violation of the right to freedom of expression, association, and peaceful assembly through arbitrary restrictions and the use of lethal force against unarmed protesters is deplorable. I also strongly condemn the detention, in an undisclosed location, of human rights lawyer Salih Mahmoud Osman – a strong advocate of legal reform in Sudan – and call for his immediate release. Other activists facing similar violations must also be released. Furthermore, I call for an end to the state-endorsed persecution of Christians, and this is a very important point for us in the EPP, the Christian Democrat Group. A free, independent and impartial press fuelled by open debate is a pillar of democratic society. The EU must therefore escalate its promotion of freedom of expression through its external policies, including in Sudan, and continue its support of human rights advocacy by civil society organisations. In addition to this, the EU must continue to work for the protection of girls’ and women’s human rights in Sudan, as highlighted by the Commissioner in May 2018. I therefore demand that the Sudanese authorities fulfil their international obligations and respond to our request.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: – Mr President, the recent political developments in Sudan are deeply concerning. We must respond with sanctions until the oppression stops. It began as a riot over steep hikes in bread prices caused by the government’s cut in wheat subsidies. It has escalated into widespread unrest with daily rallies against President Omar al-Bashir’s 29-year-old regime.  It will not surprise you that the government, led by a war criminal, have met the protests with excessive force by its security forces. Dozens have been killed. Tear gas has given way to live ammunition being used against the crowds. Security forces have arrested and beaten hundreds of journalists, medics, students and political leaders. Despite all this, the demonstrations have shown little sign of abating. The situation could grow bloodier as Bashir intends to hold onto power at any cost.  The deadly use of force must stop, as well as the harassment and intimidation of those of Darfuri origin. The right to freedom of assembly, association and expression must be guaranteed, in accordance with international law. We urge the government to immediately release all those detained and investigate all allegations of ill-treatment, arbitrary detention and excessive use of force and to hold those responsible to account.  The international community should take measures against the actions of President Bashir. Let us remember that he is still subject to an International Criminal Court (ICC) arrest warrant for war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.  I am pleased with the EU statement that actions of the government of Sudan will have an impact on our bilateral phased engagement; however, this is not enough. The international community must stop turning a blind eye to human rights violations by the Sudan regime in order to stem migration flows.  And finally, Mr President, it is high time to impose EU targeted sanctions against those responsible for grave abuses and we should review our bilateral cooperation

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, last but not least, even though some progress has been made in legislative and institutional reforms, considering the recent events which employed massive and deadly use of force, the overall democratic transformation of Sudan is very precarious, continuing to deny fundamental rights and freedom. I share the opinion that the EU and the Member States need to play a greater role in the region and to investigate these violations of human rights and humanitarian law. Moreover, every effort should be made to improve access by international humanitarian agencies to provide humanitarian aid to those in need. The EU should also intensify its efforts to promote freedom of expression through its external policies and instruments and to further strengthen financial support to human rights defenders and civil society organisations in Sudan, mainly under the European Development Fund. We should even have to take into account cutting funds to Sudan when necessary if these funds are used in an appropriate manner. Last but not least, complete transparency needs to be ensured concerning the projects in the security field with Sudan, including all planned activities and beneficiaries of EU and EU Member State funding.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: – Mr President, since massive protests started nearly a month ago sparked by price hikes but tapping the deeper reservoir of discontent, government forces have shot dead scores of protesters and detained hundreds of courageous Sudanese who courageously protested against the regime’s brutality, incompetence and corruption. As the Khartoum protests engulfed the whole country, the Sudanese Government continued to perpetrate its old tactics of arbitrary detentions and arrests, extra-judicial killings, assaults, excessive use of force and many more violations against activists, journalists and ordinary citizens. The European Union must stick to its core values and strongly condemn these persecutions and terror campaigns, and call on President Omar al-Bashir to hold those responsible to account and stop brutal confrontation against demonstrators, release all detainees, including Sakharov Price laureate Salih Mahmoud Osman, and allow the people of Sudan to exercise their constitutional rights, including the right of peaceful assembly. Once again, Madam Commissioner, the EU has to act now, not later, and must impose strong action against the government of al-Bashir, namely suspending all financial aid.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, over the past mandate of the European Parliament I was given the chance, the opportunity, to be a member of an electoral observation mission in Sudan and it was compelling to see live and first-hand the massive exercise of democratic will of the Sudanese people through a long day of voting and scrutiny.  So, it's only sad that again we see ourselves here in the European Parliament discussing massive violations of fundamental rights in Sudan under the pressure of President Bashir who has just been prosecuted by the International Court of Justice and promoting a constitutional reform, which leads to illegal detentions of those activists who care about the rule of law in Sudan.  So the usual thing is that we have these discussions with High Representative Mogherini, but it makes sense that it is you Commissioner Malmström, the one in charge of trade, who secures that there will be sanctions to this kind of behaviour, which is completely unacceptable for the international community and for the values of the European Union and what it stands for.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Mr President, oppression is on the agenda in Sudan with the famous National Intelligence and Security Service arresting, violenceing, torturing activists, students, and those who dare to demonstrate. All this has intensified, of course, since the economic crisis that exists. Although Sudan is a rich country, in practice the people are fighting for a piece of bread and, of course, President Al Bashir, who should normally be referred to the International Criminal Court, is trying to extend his mandate, because that is the only way he thinks he will be spared international criminal justice. It is therefore necessary to take measures, to impose sanctions, for Al Bashir and his group to understand that they cannot apply Islamic law, they cannot expel dissidents, they cannot expel Christian populations, and we must, Mrs Malmström, have immediate measures and sanctions against the Sudanese regime.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – Mr President, I, of course, agree with the draft resolution that we are going to vote on today. I see the situation in Sudan as much as my colleagues do. I am merely stating the sad fact that we are dealing with the situation in Sudan repeatedly here. We have repeatedly talked about the suppression of human rights in this African country and unfortunately the situation is getting worse.  I do not know if there is a solution, that is a question for you, Commissioner. Sanctions against this country need to be tightened, aid to President Bashir's regime, his people, their accounts must be frozen, more economically damaged. That's probably the only way to at least put pressure on this crazy political regime in some way, but I'm afraid we're not going to solve it completely. Even so, the adoption of these resolutions has significant symbolic value, and I hope that the Commission will turn that symbolic value into concrete actions and actions that will undermine Mr Bashir's regime.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – Mr President, first of all, we must make an analysis of what is happening in that African country, in Sudan: inequality, violence, lack of resources in the population, lack of human rights, lack of press freedom, etc., etc.  This is an X-ray, Mr President, of what is happening in many African countries. But in Sudan the current political and social landscape is increasingly worrying, because the opposition is being repressed with violence and the Government does not allow demonstrations, as it uses force to dissolve them and there are more than forty, dead without counting the wounded and detainees.  Sudan is on the doorstep of an election — in 2020 — which, I fear, given what is happening in that country, will lead to more repression of the political forces of the opposition and that those who do not dance to the son marked by the macabre President Al-Bashir will also be persecuted. And it will be pursued, let us not forget, to anyone who is a Christian and who cannot freely make use or gala of his faith.  That is why I call on the institutions of the European Union to take steps to sanction Sudan for the injustices that sudan is unfairly inflicting on its people.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the situation of human rights in Sudan is a continuous worry for the European Union. Our main areas of concern include freedom of expression, assembly and association, as well as the shrinking space for civil society. We have witnessed these fundamental rights being undermined in recent weeks by the response of the Government of Sudan to the widespread protests sparked across the country last December because of the rising cost of living and shortages.  The Sudanese security forces have responded by using force, at times live ammunition, tear gas, intimidation and arbitrary arrests. Reportedly, as you mentioned, more than 40 people have lost their lives and more than 800 people remain detained. Several media outlets, including newspapers, have been seized. Social media and the internet have been partially cut to suppress news and prevent coordination among protesters. The European Union has been alarmed by reports of the use of tear gas against medical personnel and patients in hospital. As emphasised in the most recent EU statements on the ongoing protests, we expect the Sudanese Government to release all journalists, members of the Opposition, human rights defenders and other protesters arbitrarily detained. We also expect the Government to conduct a thorough investigation into these recent deaths and abuses. It is vital that those responsible are held accountable for their actions. Furthermore, all sides should exercise restraint and abstain from any further violence in order to de—escalate the situation.  The European Union calls upon the Government of Sudan to allow the Sudanese people to exercise their constitutional right to express their views without fear of reprisal. We also call on the Government to implement much needed political and economic reforms to address the grievances expressed by the population about the challenges the country is facing. I would like to assure you that the EU will continue to stand for human rights and fundamental freedoms in Sudan, as well as to support civil society work and human right defenders by different means at our disposal.  As you know, our relations with Sudan are affected by the International Criminal Court (ICC) arrest warrant against President Bashir and subsequent decisions by Sudan not to ratify the revised Cotonou Agreement. That means that Sudan is not eligible for programme funds from the European Development Fund. However, as you know, the country is in a very dire economic and humanitarian situation. Widespread conflict and insecurity transcend borders and negatively impact the wider region. With that in mind, two years ago we made available a special measure for Sudan worth EUR 1 million for the benefit of the population. It does not mean that we are endorsing the political leadership. This money is channelled through the EU Emergency Trust Fund for Africa and it aims to improve the situation of the most vulnerable groups.  We will continue to raise concerns in our engagement with the Sudanese authorities at all levels. We will also show our continued support through the use of the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR) and this has already provided funds, for instance, to several projects on press freedom, as well as civic and human rights and education in Sudan. Thank you very much for this debate.

name: Kati PIRI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We are witnessing a huge crisis taking place in Sudan. We cannot stand passively when sharp ammunition and tear gas are used to quell the growing protests of citizens. Churches are destroyed, Christians are brutally murdered. Women and children are starving en masse, and the situation in the country is heading towards one of the biggest humanitarian crises in the history of recent decades. In the light of the many unrest on the African continent, we must measurablely counter the escalation of this crisis, support democratic change in the country of the authoritarian regime, so that the people of Sudan are not left alone. Let us use all possible means of persuasion to improve the situation of the Sudanese people.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: Writing. – In Sudan, as in any country in the world, human rights must be respected. Violence and aggression are factors that are destructive to society. The state must ensure the well-being of its inhabitants, create a favorable medium for economic prosperity. The protection of the population is an essential public function. I strongly call on the Sudanese public authorities to take immediate action to improve the human rights situation in the country. First of all, ensure access to essential food, medical and hygiene products. To help the population of areas affected by the unrest, for example, to ensure access to humanitarian aid. Order and justice will only prevail if much attention is paid to the formation of the police and judicial authorities. Governance based solely on law and compliance is effective. Man and his well-being must be a priority for the state.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: Writing. – For the past month, many mass labour - popular mobilizations of millions of Sudanese against the country's unpopular regime have been evolving due to the new wave of precision and shortages of bread, basic food and fuel. These are met with harsh repression using even real fire on protesters and have caused the deaths of several dozen protesters, injuries and arrests of several hundred. The great geopolitical interests of imperialist centres involving, among others, the EU and the rivalries of monopolies in Africa and the wider region of Sudan are expensively paid for by the peoples of the region fighting for their rights. The Communist Party condemns the bloody repression of Sudan's unpopular regime. It expresses its solidarity with the Sudanese KK and the labour-popular struggles, which are being developed for economic, social and democratic rights. It calls for an end to repression and for those arrested to be released.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, this morning Dutch journalist, Ans Boersma, was unexpectedly expelled from Turkey, and the question is whether we are dealing here again with another example of how journalism is silenced in Turkey. I would like to request that President Tajani contacts the Turkish authorities to ask for the reasons for her expulsion since no other reason was given than vague security concerns and links to terrorist organisations, and to once again highlight the concerns of this House when it comes to press freedom in Turkey.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Ms Piri, you have the support of the House and as a former journalist, I also support your calls. We will convey your message to the President.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, just as we are supposed to be raising points of order before this House and indicate which point of order it is, which paragraph, and in order that we don’t delay proceedings. We’re told this on a regular basis, just because I have similar interventions like the previous speaker, could the House indicate to me what rule of point of order that previous speaker spoke on so that I’m able to use the same in future?

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab On Tuesday, Mrs Bilbao Barandica made an inappropriate statement here in this Chamber. She said the six speakers on the euro were men. I wanted to make sure that you do not drawer people by appearance. Perhaps they feel women and are now sorry to them. Please stand up and apologize to these people and refrain for the future from such schowinistic statements. Please don't tell people who they want to be.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: author. – Madam President, we had a very good negotiation on this resolution among colleagues from all the groups who signed all together the resolution but I have to present to you two oral amendments which are technical amendments, but we want this resolution to be correct. I was expecting to get the floor for Point B and Point C of our resolution but I can present, if you agree, both technical amendments now. I would like you to agree with the following changes to Point B of the resolution: Mehman Huseynov, who is due to be released in March 2019, has been facing a possible additional five to seven year prison sentence on charges, not under the Article 315(2) but only under the Article 317(2). This is my first oral amendment and I would like you to support it.  My second oral amendment concerns the visit of the EEAS delegation to the prison where Mehman Huseynov is. This visit took place, not on 10 January, but on 11 January and after the Commissioner said in the debate that, according to EEAS, Mehman Huseynov has finished his hunger strike, the hunger strike being one of the reasons for our debate and resolution, I must say here also that family and lawyers cannot confirm that he has finished his hunger strike. Thank you for your attention and I ask you to support the technical changes.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President — don't worry, you will love to listen to me — we have the opportunity, by voting 'yes' to the mandate, to have a fisheries management plan for the western Mediterranean for the first time. That's why I'm asking for a mandate.  We have made a great effort with the agreements in the commitments, we have approved twenty-four commitments, until the last minute... We postponed the Commission's vote to reach greater agreement. We've done it.  With your yes vote we will have the possibility to carry out, for the first time in the Mediterranean fishing population, a comprehensive management plan.  This is a great opportunity. If we say no to the mandate, there will be no management plan in the Mediterranean.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, one of the most important and crucial things needed to sustain democracy in any Member State is the rule of law. Undermining the rule of law is always dangerous because it clears a way for weakening other democratic elements of the state. This is why we are voting on this report.  Let me emphasise that this regulation has its legal basis in the financial regulation. Article 322 of the Treaty, not in Article 7. This is about protecting the EU budget from generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law.  Another very important thing to understand about this report and proposal is that it has to be, and will be, the same budgetary consequences for every Member State that would undermine the rule of law.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the oral amendment reads: ‘the prevention and the sanctioning of tax evasion and the proper functioning of authorities contributing to administrative cooperation in tax matters’ – that is deleting words ‘and tax competition’ because tax competition is in the competence of the Member States and therefore does not belong in this report.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, thank you for the big support. In line with the Conference of President decision for MFF related files, I would request that Parliament refers the matter back to the committees responsible for institutional negotiations in accordance with Rule 59A.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I didn’t ask for the floor. But of course it has to be referred back to the interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like that the matter be referred back to committee for interinstitutional negotiations, pursuant to Rule 59(4).

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, when I meet people who participate in European Union programmes they talk about the need for simplification. Well, we have some simplification. As a result of this report, we’ve got a reduction in the acronym soup that we have to deal with. We have a single regime of governance and we have 13 services being brought together in a single point of contact. That simplification also provides some flexibility. It provides the flexibility to look for a programme that doesn’t necessarily fit into what was there before. GBP 38 billion of the budget guarantee and another 9.5 billion from national regional partners are just a start. The prize is the investment that that will leverage – EUR 650 billion is the Commission’s estimate. It’s a fund providing investment that direct commercial investment cannot. InvestEU brings together public and private investment in a genuine partnership for the future of economic growth.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, the level and protection of investment currently do not cover the Union's structural investment needs and do not support long-term growth. Technological change, global competition and societal challenges require ongoing support and therefore support the InvestEU Fund, because that is its objective: funding and investment that contributes to the development of research, innovation and digitalisation. Of course, this leads to employment and growth and the achievement of the objectives of the Paris Agreement on climate change. It is very important to invest in science, technology, culture, education and training. An important beneficiary of these funds can be Romania and must be Romania, which has a strong human resource in all these areas.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Madam President, we have just celebrated the 20th anniversary of the euro area, and it is good to take a critical look at the policies mentioned in the european Central Bank's latest 2017 report. While it is clear that the policy of quantitative easing has played a decisive role in maintaining the integrity of the euro area and in providing a breath of fresh air to the hard-hit countries of southern Europe, the truth is that the policies pursued are still not sufficient. Worse, far from calling for expansionary policies, made of investments that would bring the countries of the euro area together, the report proposed to us finally takes up the classic doxa on structural reforms that should be carried out, and which we know devastate European countries and entire territories. I could have voted for this report if he had put forward solutions to the phenomenon of Eurodivergence, if he had talked about investment, a transfer union, the ecb's out-of-market state debt. This is not the case, and this is a pity, because I believe that Europe deserves better than that.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab To say why I voted against this report, I will read only one sentence (recall that this is a report on trade, a trade agreement with Central America) 'recalls the commitment of the European Union and other signatories to include gender equality in trade policy; calls on the parties to accept the gender aspect of the arrangement and to promote and promote inclusion in the future review of the specific gender chapter...". I even have a title for this chapter for you, let's call it: "Trade is a woman", just as the woman was Copernicus, as the woman was Galileo and the woman was Newton.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I could not support this report in this vote, although, of course, I support the evaluation of the implementation of all trade agreements, including these, but there is one thing that bothers me, there is one element that is nothing new, but I cannot support it for fundamental reasons, and that is the thinking of introducing sanctions during the review mechanism.  I think that sanctions are not an effective tool to improve implementation, of course we have to worry about what the situation looks like, for example, in the area of human rights in these countries or in the area of environmental protection, but this will not be solved by sanctions, there are other instruments for this, and I have always, as Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Trade, opposed the imposition of sanctions, and therefore I could not support this report.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, the European Union’s approach to Central America shows an organisation that is as concerned with exporting its ideology as any revolutionary regime – Jacobin France or Bolshevist Russia or any other new organisation that wants the rest of the world to copy it. Because all of the EU’s treaties with the Central American region have been based on the principle that there must be regional integration everywhere else, that it needs to be bloc-to-bloc and that they don’t want to do trade or aid deals with individual nation-states. Central Americans have been pushed into forming supranational associations, including Parlacen, a supranational parliament. I can understand why this has happened. I’m sure people here genuinely think that regional associations are the way forward and that is valid to try and push the world in that direction. And yet, the awkward truth remains that the flow is the other way. In the 1950s when the EEC was set up there were 80 countries now there are 200. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Madam President, ten years after the financial crisis that devastated the world economy, the banking union is still not complete. Systemic banks have not yet been dismantled and continue to threaten our societies with their chronic instability. We know that in the event of a new crisis, states would be forced to put their hands in their pockets to socialize the losses of finance, as was already the case in 2008. Therefore, the promises on the responses to the 2008 crisis have been betrayed, and this umpteenth report on the state of the banking union is not really reassuring. In a way, it balances the failure of ten years of neoliberal economic policies. I think we need real answers to this situation. Deposit banks and investment banks need to be separated. Of course, we must break with fiscal austerity. Of course, there is a need for more regulation of shadow banking, which has become a source of destabilization in the global economy. Frankly, we are not up to the challenge and if we do not succeed, the crisis is ahead of us, and it is coming quickly.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I would like to explain why I could not support this report. We all care about respect for human rights in the European Union. Although the countries of the European Union are democratic, respect fundamental rights, we must not rest on our laurels and strive to fulfil these rights. Unfortunately, this report goes much further. I simply do not agree with the recommendation on the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, because this is the sovereign right of the Member States. I reject the claim agreed in the report that denial of sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights services, including safe legal abortion, constitutes one form of violence against women.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, for me and for the Socialists and Democrats the high point of 2017 was certainly the establishment of the European social pillar, and EU citizens’ basic human rights is one of the most important values. This is also one of the first things that foreigners point out when they speak about EU foreign policy. But in our home things are far from perfect. What I find really alarming in the second report of our Fundamental Rights Agency on minorities and discrimination is that discrimination is still a reality for many people in the EU. Illegal hate speech online puts the well-being of too many Europeans at risk. Inefficient integration policy brings vulnerability to migrants on our soil. I realise that in order to address such issues, the FRA need a larger mandate, but it is also true that this subject is still mainly in the hands of the Member States. But of course I voted in favour.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, we were too slow to act on Hungary and now the Council must urgently follow up on the Article 7 procedures, because our shared European values of liberal democracy matter. So let us say it like it is: a university has been forced out and academic freedom is no more, the independence of the judiciary has been threatened, minorities mistreated. Morally and strategically we must not tolerate the far-right populists, for if we do not act, we become complicit in moving the centre of gravity of politics. We saw it in the language used about refugees swamping Europe, which was tolerated. It moved from the extremes to normal public discourse taking opinion and policy with it. We see it in our history too and the ultimate horrors of World War II. Appeasing those whose principles that we despise never has worked and never will.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, I voted against my colleague's report not because money should not be given for the decommissioning of reactors in Ignalina, but because this is how I vote against the double standard in the European Union and against the force ing of decisions despite the views of its citizens. Freedom, democracy and the right of people to decide their own destiny is the greatest value and it must also be imposed in this Union. I stand behind those more than 1 million people who 10 years ago rejected the Brussels dictatorship and voted to keep their nuclear power plant. Just as we in Bulgaria have fought and continue to fight for the preservation of our completely safe nuclear facilities at Kozloduy Nuclear Power Plants. The European Union, in a not very democratic way, imposed on Bulgaria, Lithuania and Slovakia to close working nuclear plants that produced cheap electricity. He knew perfectly well that shutting down and decommissioning these nuclear plants in Kozloduy, Ignalina and Bohunice before they ran out of resources was a foolish and economically unjustified decision. However, the Union has imposed the closure of these plants. Lithuania, which relied on 70% of its consumption on this PPS, is today the largest importer of electricity from the PPS.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report because the closure of the Ignalina nuclear power plant in Lithuania is special for a number of reasons. It is special for being a pioneering and irreversible dismantling of the two graphite reactor cores, type RBMK, inherited from Soviet technology and in all similar to those used in Chernobyl.  This is a unique opportunity to acquire knowledge for the Union in the area of the dismantling of nuclear installations and radioactive waste management, and therefore the separate investment provided for in the document is justified and in particular also because it is an exceptional case to the polluter-pays principle for radioactive waste cases. Why? Because this investment in nuclear energy was imposed on the territory of Lithuania by the then Soviet Union, it was intended to serve a much wider region, and disproportionate to the size and financial capacity of Lithuania.  The closure of the nuclear power plant has led to the need to increase energy imports to serve the region, and Lithuania has therefore been bearing very high energy costs for years. I therefore believe that the Co-Financing of the Union should be done above the planning of the Euratom agreements and I hope that this case will serve as an example for the planned dismantling and ongoing in other Member States.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, I supported this proposal, I consider it the right decision that a dangerous Soviet-style nuclear power plant has been shut down, it is in the interests not only of Lithuanians, but also of the citizens of the European Union.  As a child, I experienced in Czechoslovakia when the Chernobyl nuclear reactor exploded, and the consequences were also on our territory. So, in my opinion, it is pointless to question this decision, and it is right that the European Union is involved in the dismantling of this power plant financially, and I am glad that we voted to maintain the original ratio of money that the European Union is sending to Lithuania precisely to dismantle this dangerous nuclear power plant. This clearly demonstrates the positive contribution of the European Union, which, for clear security reasons, agreed to remove this facility when Lithuania entered the European Union, it is in the interests of Europeans, Lithuanians, and I am glad that the proposal has been approved.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, I agree with the basic objective of this regulation. I would like to point out that the European Union needs to have an instrument to penalised the system, a country where systemic deficiencies in the judiciary and the civil service put the financial interests of the European Union at risk of being damaged. Although I do not agree with some aspects of the proposed process, I think that this can still be worked out in detail within the trilogue. Therefore, despite some of the reservations I have, I consider it important that the European Union should have this instrument, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, the regulation protects European money, and the risk of theft of European money is higher in states that do not respect the rule of law, where the independence of justice is at risk, where decisions are arbitrary or illegal – including those taken by public authorities – and are not corrected and are not sanctioned and where people's rights and freedoms are restricted, such as freedom of the press. In these cases, we recognise many of the decisions taken, unfortunately, in Romania by the PSD-ALDE government. Now, in these countries where the rule of law is not respected, surely European money is at risk and, as such, the regulation states that it can be suspended, frozen, reduced. In this case, that State will have to make payments, but from its own budget, and will not receive funding until it has remedied the difficulties.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, I voted strongly against this report, as I do not believe that the Commission's proposal for a new regulation on the already existing procedure laid down in Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union could achieve anything more than an unnecessary administrative burden. The imposition of financial penalties for disregard for the so-called "no-fly zone" has been imposed. 'Values of the Union' often serves to achieve illegitimate political objectives and to combat political opponents in countries.  I do not agree that citizens of the European Union have to pay the price, as they are the end users of the financial assistance presented by Brussels. It is hypocritical to violate the sovereign rules of the Member States. The examples with Hungary and Poland in recent years are eloquent. The European Union should not impose its interests on the countries and interests of countries such as France and Germany, at the expense of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, as we see, inter alia, in the Mobility Package. The imposition of financial fines will achieve nothing but scepticism and the disintegration of the existing system.  The European Union needs to be reformed because offering these double standards will do nothing good.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Madam President, I have long been hesitant to support this report or to abstain. I got late in the end. On the one hand, I very much welcome the fact that the European Union wants to defend more European values, which include the rule of law. That's an important thing. But the particular proposal does not seem to me to be entirely happy, and there are some contentious issues, as the Legal Service of the European Council has also pointed out here, and I feel that, despite some efforts to find a compromise, the question of the legal basis for this proposal remains. So I will continue to see how the debate over this proposal goes, but we need to be sure that we are adopting a proposal that is really based on the legal basis of primary European law, and it is not some extension that can be seen as an extension outside the founding treaties of the European Union.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, there are three fundamental shortcomings in this proposal. Firstly, the Commission is not apolitical. When France recently announced that it would exceed the allowable budget deficit, the Commission decided to grant it an exemption. We have no guarantee that, when assessing the rule of law, the Commission will treat France and Poland in the same way, for example. Secondly, the general wordings in the text allow their interpretation to change over time. They can also be used against legitimate actions by political opponents. Thirdly, sanctions are to be decided by the Council of the European Union by reverse qualified majority. This means that the sanctions proposed by the Commission should be automatically adopted, unless a qualified majority decides otherwise. Thus, the Council would only have the role of a court of appeal, before which few would succeed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: – Madam President, the tax arrangements by which, technically, the law does not break, have caused losses to the Union budget and national budgets, of EUR 200 billion in 2015 alone. Fraud, tax evasion, money laundering are cross-border crimes, which is why the Fiscalis 2020 programme allows national authorities in the field to exchange information and expertise, precisely in order to catch those who committed these crimes and recover money. Recovering money is the most important thing, because otherwise the source of crime continues. Combating tax evasion, fraud, money laundering must remain a priority. If that does not happen, sanctions are reached, as discussed in the Sarvamaa report earlier. Sanctions are being imposed, because the rule of law is not respected and politicians in power in that state are punished for acting against the interests of the people.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: – Madam President, I did not support my Colleague Valero's report on the establishment of the Rights and Values programme, as I believe that the purpose of this instrument is to serve as a political struggle and intervention in the internal affairs of sovereign Member States. We have all witnessed an unacceptable, undemocratic interference in the sovereign affairs of Poland and Hungary and the infamous criminal proceedings against them.  I consider the proposal to add a new specific objective that concerns democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law and within which to finance relevant actions at local, national, regional and supranational level, as hypocritical and to interfere with sovereign rights. I cannot support any report that makes references to outrageous documents such as the Istanbul Convention, which is quite obviously a political tool, given the influence of the so-called "No" vote. There is no room for such outrageous and ambiguous documents in the rights and values program.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: – Madam President, the political chaos of this week leaves two groups of people with continued and real uncertainty about their futures, EU citizens who live and work in the UK and UK citizens who live in other Member States. These people are doctors and nurses, builders and plumbers, teachers, academics, public servants, business owners and entrepreneurs. They are also mums and dads, grandparents, brothers and sisters, students and schoolchildren. These are real people. This is not an abstract set of issues, so I call upon this house, the European Union and the UK Government to resolve this to safeguard these people’s rights without delay.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, I voted for this report, along with a large majority of the European Parliament, and was glad to do so. Late payment for their goods and services is a major problem for smaller companies in practice. According to the Federation of Small Businesses in the UK, up to 85% of small businesses report that they are sometimes paid late. Seventeen per cent say that late payment happens even after the 60-day default position in the Late Payment Directive. This is completely unfair and a serious business risk for those negatively affected. Our report highlights the failure of the Late Payment Directive adequately to tackle the issue. Loopholes in the directive unfortunately allow for late payment to continue. So I welcome that we’re calling today for legislative action where necessary and appropriate to take a firmer approach against those who do not pay in time, and to pay particular attention to procurement and other processes so that smaller businesses promptly get the money they are owed from public-sector organisations.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, the idea of differentiated integration is nothing new, we already have it. The area of banking union is not the same as Schengen, it is not the same as EU, but now after all these crises we’ve been surviving, some are proposing that we should have a differentiated integration. Some countries should integrate more and be allowed to remain outside of that cooperation. As somebody who cares about the EU despite its obvious big problems, I would warn against that idea because first being a member of the European Union is to learn how to make compromise. Of course you’re not satisfied every time, but this gives us the strength to act together against the problems that we have. It is to respect the fundamental values that we in principle that we have in this Union and it is learning to solve the global problems together because without having all these countries we will never be able to cope with these global problems.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, the concept of 'differentiated integration' is not politically neutral and I believe that it cannot be regarded as such. It is a euphemism that aims to legitimize Europe at two speeds. This is the politically correct concept that divides the European Union into a centre and a periphery, of first and second-class Member States, into two categories of European citizens. Again, it is a kind of form of double standard – a topic that is especially painful for my fellow citizens.  It seems illogical to fight against the double standard in food, and at the same time for Bulgaria and Romania to be outside Schengen or to be accepted only partially. If the citizens of this Union do not feel equal, it would also negatively affect the future of the European project as a whole. Talking about Europe at several speeds in the run-up to the European elections will inevitably affect turnout, which has traditionally not been very high. That should make us think.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour because I believe that differentiation reflects the idea that Europe does not work in a single approach for all those who have the capacity to adapt to the needs and desires of European citizens.  Differentiation must be a constitutional instrument that ensures flexibility, without compromising the entire political system and equality between citizens. Standardising differentiation is to ensure that we work with the capacities of the Member States so that they can continue with the Union's development policies without creating a two-speed Europe, nor first- and second-rate Europeans.  The process of differentiation must be harmonised by ending the practices of self-exclusion and derogation from primary EU law which lead to negative differentiation, distort the homogeneity of European law and undermine the social cohesion of the Union.  But what we cannot do is give up the fundamental values of the Union and therefore its angular losses should not be open to differentiation. A future European institutional framework must inevitably include the European pillars of political, economic, social and environmental rights. No pauses are being admitted in freedom and democracy or in combating climate change.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the key to making new sense of this Europe is written in the report we have voted on today: it is called transparency. The Council can no longer afford to work behind closed doors and to secrete documents and ban their access to citizens. The Court of Justice of the European Union reiterated, in the De Capitani judgment of 2018, that the principles of openness and transparency must be ensured at all stages of the Union's legislative procedures, as they are inherent in them. If there is any real hope for this Europe to become the common home of all European citizens, including the protection of rights and the collective interest, social justice and the fight against inequalities, the development of a resilient society that is in harmony with the planet, this hope is to finally make this Europe a glass palace. , clear and transparent.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the protection of rice grown in the EU by Czeslaw Adam Siekierski on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (O—000128/2018 – B8-0004/2019) (2018/2957(RSP)).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union is the largest trading bloc in the world. This is a success for the bloc itself, but of course it would not have been possible without its citizens all these years. The position of leading trading bloc also comes with responsibilities to other countries. Therefore, the Generalised Scheme of Preferences is the right approach that enables third countries to generate economic growth and upswing, and why not one day be an equal economic partner. Of course, it should be taken into account that in many cases the cost of production is much lower than those in the European Union. The requirements for the production of agricultural products remain among the highest, if not the highest in the world, which has an enormous impact on the economic attractiveness of agriculture in Europe. Rice production in the European Union is concentrated in several countries. The rice producers from Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece, France, Hungary, Romania and, of course, the country I know best – Bulgaria, unfortunately, are the ones who felt quite strongly and on their own back some of the growth of bilateral trade between the Union and the two countries of Southeast Asia. At the first European Union Forum on Rice, held nearly 3 years ago in Milan, as you know, Mrs Malmström, representatives of various branch organisations from seven EU Member States, rallied around the need for a new approach to rice production in the European Union. We must not forget that rice production engages resources, such as water, for example, for which there are requirements; the workforce for which there are also requirements; equipment for which there are also requirements. All this is making production in the European Union more expensive. Here in the European Parliament we stand by these requirements so that there are both fertile soils and clean waters for future generations. However, I am not sure that the demand for cheaper imports is the right approach. Because resources in other parts of the world, just like in Europe, must be protected. It makes sense that rice offered and imported into the European Union from third countries meets these social and environmental requirements. In the case of both Myanmar and Cambodia, the economic impact of the application of the Generalised Scheme of Preferences is significant. Trade trade between the two countries, on the one hand, and the European Union, on the other, for the period 2015-2017 there is a significant increase, which means that the approach is correct. Unfortunately, however, some European sectors feel this growth on their backs more than others, and quite negatively. One of these sectors is also rice production. In this regard, today, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I would be interested in initiating a question and debate on rice imports from third countries, in particular From Myanmar and Cambodia. I am glad that it is you, Commissioner, who are here with us and together we can send the positive message to European rice growers. Most heartily, and I am sure my other colleagues, welcome the decision taken by the European Commission, as of tomorrow, 18 January 2019, to introduce a new regime for imports of rice from these two countries. Today's publication in the Official Journal of the European Union is the result of a lot of work and effort on the part of both rice growers and the European Commission, of course. The survey carried out on imports of semi-milled and milled Indica rice originating in Cambodia and Myanmar for the period 2012-2017 outlines trends already familiar to the sector in Europe. Imports from the two countries considered together have doubled over this period, but I would like to draw attention to the huge increase in imports from Myanmar, which from 2 000 tonnes in 2012 to 2017 reached nearly 63 000 tonnes. This growth of 3 000% is huge and it would not be fair to remain unchanged. Low production costs in Cambodia and Myanmar are one of the factors that have shrunk European production by nearly 40% in just 4-5 years. This can't help but worry among the biggest supporters of free trade. Account must also be taken of the downward trend in rice consumption in the European Union, which, among other things, may also be due to a change in the European diet. I regrettably informed myself of the delays in communication with southeast Asian partners. I believe that cooperation with them should continue, but I strongly welcome the proposed introduction of rice duties over the next three years. I believe that the progressive reduction of these duties will enable European rice producers to recover and continue to produce a quality product. European industry has also already sent strong messages of support for the proposed measure. I am pleased that while on some issues we here in the European Parliament have different views from the Commission, in this case today and hence we manage to send a strong signal of support european rice production. I also welcome the decision of "..." (the President takes away the speaker's word)

name: André ELISSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Cambodia and Myanmar are beneficiaries of the ‘Everything But Arms’ arrangement and that grants least developed countries duty and quota free access to the European market. This is one important pillar of our Generalised Scheme Preferences (GSP) tariff reduction scheme for developing countries. Nevertheless, under the rules of the general scheme of preferences of the regulation, the Commission may, temporarily, reinstate the common customs tariffs duties to shield a particular sector if products are imported in volumes or at a price that are causing serious difficulties to EU industries. Upon the request of eight rice producing Member States, the Commission initiated a safeguard investigation regarding imports of indica rice from Cambodia and Myanmar. The findings of these investigations confirm that there is indeed a surge of imports of rice that has caused economic damage to the rice sector in the EU. The imports of indica rice from Cambodia and Myanmar have increased significantly over the he last year. Imports from Cambodia have increased by almost 100 000 tonnes and Myanmar by 60 000 tonnes and this represents a significant increase of market share – from 15% to 25% for Cambodia and from zero to 6% from Myanmar. Import prices were much lower than the EU prices and, as a result, the EU industry lost a significant volume of production and market share. Therefore, it is warranted that safeguard measures are imposed and the Commission will reinstate the common customs tariff duty. The tariff duty will be EUR 175 per tonne in year one, EUR 150 per tonne per in year two and EUR 125 per tonne in year three. These measures will therefore be in place for three years and they can only be extended in duly justified circumstances. The measures will give breathing space for the EU rice sector to allow them to adopt to the new market conditions. We have, from the Commission, adopted the implementing regulation yesterday and the decision has been published this morning.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Rice production plays an important role in my country, Hungary, on the northern border of the European Union rice production zone, as the demand for labour is much higher than in other arable crop sectors. Thus, it provides livelihoods for local people in the areas most affected by unemployment. In addition, rice cultivation is useful from an environmental and soil point of view.  Like other agricultural sectors, we must ensure fair competition for rice growers in the EU in the face of increasing imports from third countries. Dumped imports of Cambodian and Myanmar indica rice, in addition to causing significant damage, are defrequested by fair international trade. I therefore fully support what has been described in this parliamentary question and ask the European Commission to immediately launch a safeguards investigation under Article 22 of the General System of Tariffs Regulation. Thank you so much for listening.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, rice imports from South-East Asia, namely from Cambodia and Myanmar, have become a sensitive issue for the EU in the last two years. I noted that European rice producers have become more and more vocal on human rights and labour standards violation in Cambodia and Myanmar, linking these issues to the GSP+ provisions. We all know that the general scheme of preference (GSP) has three objectives, to contribute to poverty eradication by expanding exports from countries most in need. Secondly, to promote sustainable development and good governance and ensure that the EU’s financial and economic interests are safeguarded. I agree that if we produce a human rights clause into our trade agreements, it has to be respected and GSP+ can be revoked in case of non-compliance. But don’t you see a moral issue in the fact that we start to point the finger at labour standards in Asia only after the economic interests of European companies get affected? Personally I do. The ‘Everything but Arms’ (EBA) arrangement is a preferential arrangement, and we need to keep in mind that granting tax exceptions for imports is our right but not our obligation. Therefore, I suggest that the European Commission has a very close look on how our EBA agreements are applied. Human rights promotions and protection is the flagship of the EU activity and we cannot discredit our international engagement in human rights by giving preferences to those sources who blatantly abuse workers. This makes the EU inconsistent in the eyes of the world and weakens our credibility. I can understand that revoking a preferential status after it has been granted is a politically painful act that we all would like to avoid, but that is why I want to underline once more the Commission’s duty of oversight, so that EBA preferences are given only if our partner has a concrete strategy for human rights improvement. On 16 March 2018, the Commission decided to initiate a safeguard investigation to clarify the impact of indica rice imports. We in the European Parliament here are waiting for the results to have some predictability for our rice industry. The stakes are high. Only in case of Italy, we are speaking about 4 265 farms and more than 100 rice companies generating annual turnover of more than EUR 1 billion euros. These companies are heavily jeopardised now. Concluding, I want to say that the revocation of the GSP+ can bring about a positive change in the markets of South Asia. It will lead them to rely less on exports to the EU, develop more added-value products and raise the standards of working conditions.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, let me first congratulate the colleague who raised this question, Colleague Nakov. I rely on it as due diligence that each of us must express for the protection of our producers, whether they are from one Member State or another of the European Union. These people who work, create gross domestic product, pay taxes and end up supporting countries and the Union as such. Yes, there is no doubt that the importation of any goods from the outside, including the product referred to – in this case rice – must take place only under conditions which would not jeopardise would not put local producers at risk. And in this case, that's what we're talking about. The importation of large quantities of rice from those Countries mentioned in the oral question endangers local producers.  The working conditions in these countries, the respect for human rights that my colleague Mamiekins was talking about, are clearly not at the level at which we put conditions before our producers. Every week here we look at dozens of reports concerning exactly these two countries – Myanmar (Burma) or Cambodia. We simultaneously raise these issues, discuss them, adopt resolutions, but at the same time accept their goods, which, however, threaten and violate the rights of our manufacturer. Therefore, Commissioner, it is absolutely imperative that we avoid this double standard in relation to favoured third parties and insist that these producers comply with at least the minimum standards we impose on our producers. Otherwise, we finance producers from other countries and doom our producers to great difficulties. They must comply with all European standards and at the same time cannot compete with cheaper goods imported from the outside. It is mandatory to introduce these duties. (The Speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask you: the standards that you are referring to are the same arguments that western European countries refer to against the countries of Eastern Europe when, for example, they want to introduce this mobility package, to prevent competition, as they call 'social dumping'. Do you not think that it is hypocritical to invoke this? Do not do unsave to others.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – I agree, honourable Member, that there is a double standard and hypocrisy when we speak within the Union. But in this case, the conversation is about protecting the interests of the Hungarian producers, the Polish producers, the Bulgarian producers. In this case, we must be united around protecting our jobs within our countries. Otherwise, you are right about double standards in the Union.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, following the decisions taken on Wednesday it is particularly appropriate to use a Spanish saying to congratulate the European Commission. Brussels has prevented us from 'getting the rice'. This expression is used in Spanish, in many areas, to underline how dangerous it is not to make decisions in time. In response to the complaint of producers, it has reacted quickly and forcefully. European sovereignty has been used to protect an unde transformed European agricultural product from unfair competition from third countries under the widespread preference regime. This combats Euroscepticism: demonstrating in the Albufera of Valencia, in the Ebro Delta, Lombardy or Piedmont, among others, that Brussels, that Europe is useful; explaining that this safeguard clause is strong, durable and also effective; stressing that, only as a Union, we have been able to meet the challenge of imports that have multiplied by forty in five years, which has clearly affected the market share of European producers, production and prices. This reduction has ranged, according to European growing areas, in percentages ranging from 10% to 30%, which has had an impact on employment and profitability. And the existence of a negative effect on these parameters is precisely the condition required by the Regulation to activate such measures. That's how Europe is built. But also dedicating all efforts to keep our farmers gaining positions in the value chain of their productions. And that requires helping them partner, innovate, participate in the marketing, distribution and transformation industry. Under these conditions, such import operations, typical of the logics handled by the large distribution, would be less common. Let us therefore greet this measure. And we combat Euroscepticism by spreading it, creating it and encouraging it and helping our producers partner, and fostering training, innovation and other marketing chains that integrate our values of environmental, social and economic sustainability.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: – Mr President, it’s not very crowded this debate and many speakers here, of whom I’m not going to be one, have spent a lot of time on their speeches. May I perhaps, on behalf of the peoples of Europe, request that you be less aggressive with the hammer on reducing people’s time? It’s really not necessary today, really not necessary and you should know better.
